Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: The summary contains detailed factual information about the lawsuit filing, the Department of Education’s actions against IES, the cancellation of contracts and staff reductions, the impact on research and data access, the legal claims under the APA, the court’s preliminary injunction denial, the narrowing of claims, and the statutory context of IES. I identified these facts by locating sentences that describe events, actions, and legal arguments, and extracted them as evidence. The extracted value summarizes the factual basis of the case.

evidence: On April 4, 2025, two nonprofit organizations—the Association for Education Finance and Policy (an association of scholars and practitioners) and the Institute for Higher Education Policy (a nonpartisan higher‑education research group)—filed this non‑class action in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Secretary of Education, in her official capacity, and the U.S. Department of Education.

The case arises from Department of Education decisions beginning in February 2025 affecting the Institute of Education Sciences (IES). Plaintiffs allege that the Department, after urging from an internal “Department of Government Efficiency,” canceled scores of IES contracts around February 10–11, 2025; announced a reduction‑in‑force on March 11, 2025 that would eliminate roughly 90% of IES positions (placing affected staff on administrative leave as of March 21); and ended or curtailed researchers’ access to IES restricted‑use datasets by terminating the remote access program effective June 1, later extended to June 30, and pausing processing of new restricted‑data license applications and disclosure‑risk reviews.

Cancellations alleged in the pleadings include major statistics and longitudinal studies (e.g., National Postsecondary Student Aid Study, Beginning Postsecondary Students Longitudinal Study, High School and Beyond 2022, High School Longitudinal Study of 2009 third follow‑up, and the Early Childhood Longitudinal Study‑Kindergarten:2024), technical assistance and dissemination activities (e.g., Regional Educational Laboratories, What Works Clearinghouse work in progress), and support functions (e.g., DataLab platform maintenance, peer review of grants, National Library of Education services, NCES mail center).

Plaintiffs contend these actions halt ongoing research, risk destruction or inaccessibility of data collected with federal funds, and prevent IES from performing statutory duties under the Education Sciences Reform Act of 2002 (ESRA) and other statutes.
Plaints also point to delays or stoppages in disclosure‑risk reviews needed to publish research using restricted‑use data.

The original complaint asserted claims under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), 5 U.S.C. § 706, including: actions contrary to law (citing ESRA provisions such as 20 U.S.C. §§ 9511–12, 9531–33, 9541–46, 9561–64, 9567, 9574–76; the Higher Education Opportunity Act, 20 U.S.C. § 1015a(k); and other program‑specific statutes), arbitrary‑and‑capricious decisionmaking, violations of the Impoundment Control Act and Anti‑Deficiency Act, and a nonstatutory ultra vires/separation‑of‑powers claim.

Plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to set aside the cancellations and RIF, prevent destruction of records, reinstate staff and programs necessary to carry out IES’s mandates, and halt termination of restricted‑data access.

On April 17, 2025, plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction to stop the Department from terminating IES functions, to reinstate programs and employees necessary to perform statutory duties, to suspend the planned end of remote restricted‑data access, and to rescind contract termination notices.

The Court held a joint hearing on May 16, 2025, together with a related case filed by the National Academy of Education and the National Council on Measurement in Education (No. 1:25‑cv‑01266); the Court did not formally consolidate the cases but heard them together under Rule 42(a).
On June 3, 2025, Judge McFadden denied preliminary‑injunction motions in both cases.

The Court held that plaintiffs had not shown a likelihood of success on the merits because their claims, as presented for preliminary relief, amounted to an impermissible programmatic challenge under the APA.

Relying on Lujan v. National Wildlife Federation and Norton v. Southern Utah Wilderness Alliance, the Court concluded that plaintiffs bundled many discrete actions (contract cancellations, staffing reductions, and access changes) into a request for wholesale judicial modification of IES operations and ongoing statutory compliance, relief the APA does not provide.
The Court also rejected the constitutional/separation‑of‑powers framing as a repackaged statutory challenge barred by Dalton v. Specter.
Because likelihood of success was not shown, the Court did not need to reach the remaining preliminary‑injunction factors.
After that ruling, plaintiffs narrowed their claims.

On June 18, 2025, they filed a First Amended Complaint focusing on eight discrete terminations: NPSAS 2024; BPS:20/25; HSLS:09 third follow‑up; HS&B:22; ECLS‑K:2024; IES’s peer‑review program for new grant funding; the remote‑access program for restricted‑use data; and the processing of new applications for access to restricted‑use data.
They also added an APA § 706(1) claim by IHEP for unreasonable delay in three disclosure‑risk review submissions (filed February 7, March 4, and March 14, 2025).

On July 16, 2025, plaintiffs filed a Second Amended Complaint further narrowing to six challenged actions: termination of BPS:20/25 (APA arbitrary‑and‑capricious); termination of HSLS:09 third follow‑up (arbitrary‑and‑capricious); termination of HS&B:22 (arbitrary‑and‑capricious); termination of ECLS‑K:2024 (arbitrary‑and‑capricious); termination of IES’s peer‑review program for new grants (contrary to 20 U.S.C. §§ 9534(b)(1), 9520, and arbitrary‑and‑capricious); and termination (pause) of processing applications for restricted‑use data (contrary to 20 U.S.C. §§ 9574, 9575(2)–(3), 9546(e)(2), and arbitrary‑and‑capricious).
IHEP’s unreasonable‑delay claim regarding disclosure‑risk reviews remains.

Plaintiffs continue to seek declaratory relief, orders setting aside the terminations, injunctions requiring resumption of the specified studies and the peer‑review program, resumption of processing restricted‑data applications, and an order compelling resolution of IHEP’s pending disclosure‑risk review requests within 14 days, along with fees and costs.

Significant proceedings include: the preliminary‑injunction denial (Memorandum Opinion, June 3, 2025); plaintiffs’ amendments narrowing to discrete actions (June 18 and July 16, 2025); and the government’s motion to dismiss the first amended complaint (mooted by the second amendment).
The Court set a briefing schedule for a renewed motion to dismiss: government motion due August 19, 2025; plaintiffs’ opposition due September 18, 2025; and reply due October 9, 2025.
As reflected on the docket, the renewed motion was filed on August 19, 2025. No appeals, trials, settlements, monitors, or decrees have been entered.

Factual context offered in the pleadings and declaration explains IES’s statutory role under ESRA to lead federal education research and statistics through four centers (NCER, NCES, NCEE, NCSER), the statutory requirements to collect and disseminate specified data (including longitudinal surveys and NAEP), to maintain peer review for grants and publications, and to make data public while safeguarding confidentiality.

Plaintiffs allege that contract cancellations and staff reductions halted multi‑year, congressionally funded studies midstream, jeopardized existing datasets and public dissemination tools (e.g., DataLab), and cut off or delayed researcher access to restricted‑use data and necessary disclosure approvals, harming their ability—and their members’ ability—to conduct and publish evidence‑based research relied upon by policymakers and the public.
extracted.value: The case involves a lawsuit filed by the Association for Education Finance and Policy and the Institute for Higher Education Policy on April 4, 2025, alleging that the Department of Education, after internal urging, canceled numerous Institute of Education Sciences contracts in February 2025, announced a 90% reduction‑in‑force on March 11, 2025, and terminated remote access to restricted‑use data, thereby halting major longitudinal studies and research programs and risking destruction of federally funded data. Plaintiffs claim these actions violate the Administrative Procedure Act and other statutes, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief. The court denied preliminary injunctions on June 3, 2025, finding the claims impermissible programmatic challenges. Plaintiffs then narrowed their claims in June and July 2025 to specific terminations of studies, peer‑review programs, and data‑access processes, and continue to seek relief. The factual context explains IES’s statutory role under the Education Sciences Reform Act and the impact of the cancellations on ongoing research and data dissemination.

evidence: On April 4, 2025, two nonprofit organizations—the Association for Education Finance and Policy (an association of scholars and practitioners) and the Institute for Higher Education Policy (a nonpartisan higher‑education research group)—filed this non‑class action in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Secretary of Education, in her official capacity, and the U.S. Department of Education. Plaintiffs are represented by the Public Citizen Litigation Group (public‑interest counsel).

The original complaint asserted claims under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), 5 U.S.C. § 706, including: actions contrary to law (citing ESRA provisions such as 20 U.S.C. §§ 9511–12, 9531–33, 9541–46, 9561–64, 9567, 9574–76; the Higher Education Opportunity Act, 20 U.S.C. § 1015a(k); and other program‑specific statutes), arbitrary‑and‑capricious decisionmaking, violations of the Impoundment Control Act and Anti‑Deficiency Act, and a nonstatutory ultra vires/separation‑of‑powers claim. Plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to set aside the cancellations and RIF, prevent destruction of records, reinstate staff and programs necessary to carry out IES’s mandates, and halt termination of restricted‑data access.

evidence: On June 3, 2025, Judge McFadden denied preliminary‑injunction motions in both cases.

The Court held that plaintiffs had not shown a likelihood of success on the merits because their claims, as presented for preliminary relief, amounted to an impermissible programmatic challenge under the APA.

Relying on Lujan v. National Wildlife Federation and Norton v. Southern Utah Wilderness Alliance, the Court concluded that plaintiffs bundled many discrete actions (contract cancellations, staffing reductions, and access changes) into a request for wholesale judicial modification of IES operations and ongoing statutory compliance, relief the APA does not provide.
The Court also rejected the constitutional/separation‑of‑powers framing as a repackaged statutory challenge barred by Dalton v. Specter.

evidence: On March 31, 2025, civil‑rights and voter‑advocacy organizations filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia challenging President Trump’s March 25, 2025 Executive Order 14,248, “Preserving and Protecting the Integrity of American Elections.” Two related cases—one by national Democratic Party entities and congressional leaders and one by additional nonpartisan voter organizations—were filed March 31 and April 1, 2025. On April 3, 2025, Judge Colleen Kollar‑Kotelly consolidated the three cases.

The plaintiffs are nonpartisan organizations engaged in voter registration and voter assistance (including the League of United Latin American Citizens, Secure Families Initiative, Arizona Students’ Association, League of Women Voters entities, Hispanic Federation, NAACP, OCA–Asian Pacific American Advocates, and Asian and Pacific Islander American Vote) and political organizations and leaders (the Democratic National Committee, Democratic Governors Association, DSCC, DCCC, and the U.S. House and Senate Democratic leaders).

The Executive Order directed, among other things: (1) the EAC to add a documentary‑proof‑of‑citizenship requirement to the national mail voter registration form (the NVRA “Federal Form”), dictate the acceptable documents, and require states to record document details; (2) agencies to open federal databases to aid citizenship verification and to review state voter rolls and list‑maintenance records against federal immigration databases; (3) the Secretary of Defense to add proof‑of‑citizenship and “proof of eligibility” requirements to the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act (UOCAVA) Federal Post Card Application; (4) the Attorney General to “enforce” federal Election Day statutes “against States” that count mail ballots received after Election Day; and (5) the EAC to condition federal election funding on states’ adoption of an Election Day ballot‑receipt deadline (with a UOCAVA carve‑out).

The court held that plaintiffs had standing to challenge the order’s directive that the EAC require documentary proof of citizenship on the Federal Form and that they were likely to succeed on the merits because the Constitution vests election regulation with the states, subject to congressional—not presidential—oversight, and Congress expressly delegated the Federal Form’s content and rulemaking to the independent, bipartisan EAC, operating through consultation with state election officials and APA/PRA procedures. The court preliminarily enjoined the EAC, its commissioners, and its executive director from taking any action to implement Section 2(a) of the order, including any change to require documentary proof of citizenship on the Federal Form. The court also enjoined implementation of Section 2(d), holding that ordering federal voter‑registration agencies to “assess citizenship” before providing the Federal Form to public‑assistance enrollees conflicts with the NVRA’s mandate that designated agencies “shall” distribute and accept the Federal Form with each application for service or assistance (unless the applicant declines in writing). The court enjoined the Departments of Defense, Veterans Affairs, and the Interior, the Small Business Administration, and their leaders from implementing Section 2(d). No bond was required.

Plaintiffs brought ultra vires separation‑of‑powers and federalism claims and statutory claims under the National Voter Registration Act (NVRA), the Help America Vote Act (HAVA), the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), the Paperwork Reduction Act, UOCAVA, and (for the Democratic Party plaintiffs) the Privacy Act.

Legal bases: Plaintiffs’ claims rest on the Elections Clause and related constitutional provisions (U.S. Const. art. I, § 4, cl. 1; art. II), NVRA (52 U.S.C. § 20501 et seq.), HAVA (52 U.S.C. § 20901 et seq., §§ 21001–21003, § 21081(a)(6)), UOCAVA (52 U.S.C. § 20301 et seq.), the APA (5 U.S.C. § 706), the Paperwork Reduction Act (44 U.S.C. §§ 3501–3521), and the Privacy Act (5 U.S.C. § 552a).
extracted.value: The case involves civil‑rights and voter‑advocacy organizations filing suit on March 31, 2025, challenging President Trump’s March 25, 2025 Executive Order 14,248; the plaintiffs include the League of United Latin American Citizens, Secure Families Initiative, Arizona Students’ Association, League of Women Voters entities, Hispanic Federation, NAACP, OCA–Asian Pacific American Advocates, and Asian and Pacific Islander American Vote, among others, and the defendants include the Executive Office of the President, the U.S. Election Assistance Commission, the U.S. Departments of Justice and Defense, and the Federal Voting Assistance Program; the order directed the EAC to add a documentary‑proof‑of‑citizenship requirement to the National Mail Voter Registration Form (the Federal Form) and other measures; plaintiffs asserted ultra‑vires separation‑of‑powers, federalism, and statutory claims under the NVRA, HAVA, APA, Paperwork Reduction Act, UOCAVA, and the Privacy Act; the court preliminarily enjoined the EAC from implementing Section 2(a) and other provisions, maintaining the status quo pending further proceedings; background information includes the Elections Clause, the delegation of the Federal Form to the EAC, and the statutory framework governing federal voter registration.

evidence: The court denied preliminary relief as to three other provisions. It declined to enjoin Section 2(b) (inter‑agency and state/federal data‑sharing to identify “unqualified voters”), finding the claims unripe because the order’s savings clauses require lawful implementation and it was unclear which, if any, Privacy Act‑implicating disclosures would occur. It denied an injunction against Section 7(a) (directing the Attorney General to “enforce” Election Day statutes against states that count ballots received after Election Day), reasoning that how, and whether, enforcement might proceed remained unclear and any enforcement would be against states, not the organizational or party plaintiffs. It denied relief against Section 7(b) (directing the EAC to condition funding on states’ adoption of an Election Day receipt rule) for lack of a substantial likelihood of standing on the present record; the court noted that any direct claim about state funding conditions would more naturally be brought by states and referenced state actions already pending elsewhere (California v. evidence: The court held that plaintiffs had standing to challenge the order’s directive that the EAC require documentary proof of citizenship on the Federal Form and that they were likely to succeed on the merits because the Constitution vests election regulation with the states, subject to congressional—not presidential—oversight, and Congress expressly delegated the Federal Form’s content and rulemaking to the independent, bipartisan EAC, operating through consultation with state election officials and APA/PRA procedures.
After expedited briefing and a hearing on April 17, 2025, the court issued a detailed memorandum opinion and order on April 24, 2025.

evidence: The court preliminarily enjoined the EAC, its commissioners, and its executive director from taking any action to implement Section 2(a) of the order, including any change to require documentary proof of citizenship on the Federal Form. The court also enjoined implementation of Section 2(d), holding that ordering federal voter‑registration agencies to “assess citizenship” before providing the Federal Form to public‑assistance enrollees conflicts with the NVRA’s mandate that designated agencies “shall” distribute and accept the Federal Form with each application for service or assistance (unless the applicant declines in writing). The court enjoined the Departments of Defense, Veterans Affairs, and the Interior, the Small Business Administration, and their leaders from implementing Section 2(d). No bond was required.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: I identified the core factual basis of the case from the summary: the enactment of Senate Bill 5375 on May 2, 2025, the lawsuit filed by Catholic clergy on May 29, 2025, their allegations that the bill forces them to violate confessional privilege, the preliminary injunction granted on July 18, 2025, and background context including House Bill 1171 and US intervention. I extracted verbatim statements supporting each part of this factual narrative.

evidence: On May 2, 2025, Washington enacted Senate Bill 5375 (effective July 27, 2025) adding “any member of the clergy” to the list of mandatory reporters of suspected child abuse or neglect and eliminating the ability of clergy to rely on state‑law privileges when learning such information, including in confessional communications.

The bishops and priests allege SB 5375 compels them to violate the Catholic Church’s sacramental seal of Confession, under threat of criminal prosecution (a gross misdemeanor punishable by up to 364 days in jail and a $5,000 fine) and civil liability, and that their dioceses already require reporting suspected abuse and neglect learned outside Confession.

July 18, 2025: The court granted a preliminary injunction. It held the bishops and priests had standing and that their claims were ripe. On the merits, the court found a likelihood of success on the Free Exercise claim: SB 5375 burdens religious practice and is not neutral or generally applicable because it treats comparable secular activity more favorably (e.g., preserves attorney‑client confidentiality for university attorneys under SHB 1171 while denying religious confidentiality to clergy).

Scope and Terms of the Preliminary Injunction: In light of the Supreme Court’s guidance on injunction breadth, the court enjoined enforcement of SB 5375 “as to the Sacrament of Confession” against the bishops, priests, and all Roman Catholic priests in Washington who fall directly under the administration of the Archbishop of Seattle and the Bishops of Yakima and Spokane.

The United States moved to intervene; the court granted intervention on July 15, 2025. The United States separately moved for a preliminary injunction on June 25, 2025, and later withdrew that motion after the court ruled on the plaintiffs’ motion.

Proceeding under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and Ex parte Young, the bishops and priests assert violations of the First Amendment’s Free Exercise and Establishment Clauses, the church‑autonomy doctrine (matters of internal governance and discipline), the Fourteenth Amendment’s Equal Protection Clause, and Article I, § 11 of the Washington Constitution.
extracted.value: The case involves the enactment of Washington Senate Bill 5375 on May 2, 2025, adding clergy as mandatory reporters and eliminating their privilege in confessional communications, and a lawsuit filed by the Archbishop of Seattle, Bishops of Yakima and Spokane, and several priests on May 29, 2025, alleging that the bill compels them to violate the Catholic Church’s sacramental seal of Confession under threat of criminal prosecution and civil liability. The case is supported by the court’s preliminary injunction granted on July 18, 2025, which enjoined enforcement of SB 5375 ‘as to the Sacrament of Confession’ against these clergy, and background information that the bill takes effect July 27, 2025, that House Bill 1171 preserves attorney‑client confidentiality for university attorneys, and that the United States intervened in the case citing equal protection grounds.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: I identified key factual events—ICE enforcement on June 6, protests, federalization orders on June 7-9, the lawsuit filed on June 9, the alleged statutory violations, and background context such as local law enforcement response and resource diversion concerns—by scanning the summary for statements that describe what happened, when, where, and who. I extracted text snippets that directly support these facts and compiled them into a concise factual basis summary.

evidence: On June 9, 2025, the Governor of California and the State of California filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the President of the United States, the Secretary of Defense, and the U.S. Department of Defense.

Represented by the California Attorney General’s Office (public counsel), the plaintiffs challenged the federalization and deployment of California National Guard units and Marines in Los Angeles that followed federal immigration enforcement operations and public protests beginning June 6, 2025.

The complaint alleges ultra vires action, violations of the Tenth Amendment, and violations of the Administrative Procedure Act, arising from the President’s June 7 memorandum invoking 10 U.S.C. § 12406 to call “at least 2,000” National Guard troops into federal service to protect federal personnel and property at sites where protests were occurring or likely to occur, followed by Department of Defense orders on June 7 and June 9 federalizing a total of 4,000 California National Guard members for 60 days, and the deployment of approximately 700 active‑duty Marines from Camp Pendleton.

Plaintiffs assert the statutory predicates for § 12406 were not met (no “rebellion” or “invasion,” and the President was not “unable with the regular forces to execute the laws”), that the statute’s directive that orders be issued “through the governors” was not followed, that use of federalized forces for civilian law enforcement would violate the Posse Comitatus Act (18 U.S.C. § 1385), and that diverting the Guard intrudes on the State’s police powers during wildfire season and drug interdiction operations.

Factual context in the record reflects that on June 6, 2025, ICE conducted enforcement operations in multiple Los Angeles locations, leading to protests at the Roybal Federal Building and other sites.

The record shows largely peaceful demonstrations with some incidents of violence and property damage; local law enforcement (LAPD, LASD, CHP) responded, declared unlawful assemblies, and made arrests.

On June 7, the President invoked § 12406 to federalize National Guard units “to temporarily protect” federal personnel and property at locations of protests; on June 7 and June 9, the Secretary of Defense ordered a total of 4,000 California National Guard members into federal service for 60 days, and announced deployment of Marines.

Plaintiffs contend the orders bypassed the Governor and diverted critical Guard resources (including wildfire and counter‑drug teams), and that statements by federal officials suggested an intent to embed troops alongside ICE operations in the community, raising Posse Comitatus concerns.
extracted.value: The case involves the Governor of California and the State filing suit on June 9, 2025, challenging the President’s June 7 memorandum and DoD orders that federalized 4,000 California National Guard members and deployed 700 Marines to Los Angeles following ICE enforcement operations on June 6, 2025, alleging ultra vires, Tenth Amendment, and APA violations, with background information including ICE operations, local law enforcement response, and concerns that the orders bypassed the Governor and diverted critical Guard resources.

evidence: On June 19, 2025, the Ninth Circuit (Judges Bennett, Miller, and Sung) granted a stay pending appeal, concluding defendants had made a strong showing of likely success. The court held the President’s § 12406 federalization decision is reviewable but subject to highly deferential review, and that the record likely satisfied § 12406(3) (“unable with the regular forces to execute the laws”), given evidence that protesters impeded ICE and other federal officers and damaged federal property. It also found that transmission of the order to the Adjutant General—who under California law issues orders in the Governor’s name—likely satisfied the statute’s “through the governors” requirement; in any event, any procedural defect would not warrant the breadth of the TRO. The panel emphasized that its decision did not address the nature of any activities that could implicate the Posse Comitatus Act, which plaintiffs had not pressed on appeal (Order granting stay pending appeal, No. 25‑3727 (9th Cir. June 19, 2025) (for publication)).

The court permitted limited expedited discovery, entered a stipulated protective order, and, under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 65(a)(2), set a consolidated bench trial on the merits for August 11–13, 2025, with public Zoom access.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: The summary provides specific dates, parties, actions, allegations, and evidence, which together form the factual basis of the case.

evidence: On March 25, 2025, two national unions that represent higher‑education faculty and academic staff—the American Association of University Professors and the American Federation of Teachers—filed suit in the Southern District of New York against several federal agencies and officials, including the Department of Justice (DOJ), the Department of Education (ED), the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), the National Institutes of Health (NIH), and the General Services Administration (GSA).
The suit arises from a series of federal actions taken in early March 2025 following a DOJ‑led “Task Force to Combat Anti‑Semitism” and ED’s announcement of Title VI investigations.

On March 7, 2025, DOJ, HHS, ED, and GSA announced the immediate cancellation of approximately $400 million in federal grants and contracts with Columbia University, citing the University’s continued inaction in the face of harassment of Jewish students.

NIH, citing 2 C.F.R. § 200.340(a)(4) and the NIH Grants Policy Statement, notified Columbia that more than 400 NIH awards totaling over $250 million were terminated because the awards no longer effectuated agency priorities.
HHS invoked the Federal Acquisition Regulation clause permitting termination for the government’s convenience (FAR 52.249‑5) on certain contracts.

On March 13, 2025, HHS, ED, and GSA sent Columbia a letter describing nine “preconditions” for negotiations about “continued” federal funding, including: completing discipline for encampments and the Hamilton Hall occupation (with expulsions or multi‑year suspensions); abolishing the University Judicial Board; adopting time, place, and manner rules and a mask policy; holding student groups accountable; adopting a definition of antisemitism; empowering campus security to remove or arrest agitators; placing Columbia’s Middle East, South Asian, and African Studies department in academic receivership; and delivering a plan for comprehensive admissions reform.

On March 21, Columbia announced an 18‑point set of measures to combat discrimination and antisemitism; the University represented in separate litigation that these measures had been under development for months and did not match the federal “preconditions” point‑for‑point.
The unions sued to stop what they characterized as unconstitutional coercion of a private university and a circumvention of Title VI’s procedural safeguards.

Their complaint alleged: (1) First Amendment violations of academic freedom and free speech, including impermissible coercion of a private party to suppress disfavored speech; (2) unconstitutional conditions on federal funding; (3) Administrative Procedure Act (APA) procedural and substantive violations, asserting that the government terminated or refused to continue assistance without the notice, opportunity for hearing, congressional reporting, and program‑specific tailoring required by Title VI (42 U.S.C. § 2000d‑1) and agency regulations; (4) separation‑of‑powers/ultra vires violations; (5) Fifth Amendment due‑process violations, claiming protected property interests in grant‑funded salaries and research; and (6) Tenth Amendment and Spending Clause violations, arguing that the government’s threats and conditions amounted to coercion beyond federal authority.

The unions sought declaratory relief, a preliminary and permanent injunction restoring the approximately $400 million and barring any further termination, pausing, or conditioning of funds without Title VI procedures, monetary damages (including compensatory and nominal), and attorneys’ fees.
extracted.value: The case involves the filing by the American Association of University Professors and the American Federation of Teachers on March 25, 2025, alleging that the federal government, specifically the DOJ, ED, HHS, NIH, and GSA, unconstitutionally coerced Columbia University by terminating about $400 million in federal grants and contracts on March 7, 2025, and imposing nine preconditions for continued funding in a letter on March 13, 2025. The plaintiffs claim violations of the First Amendment, the APA, Title VI, and other constitutional provisions, seeking to restore the terminated funds and prevent future cuts without Title VI procedures. The evidence supporting these claims includes the March 7 cancellation announcement, the NIH termination notice citing 2 C.F.R. § 200.340(a)(4) and the NIH Grants Policy Statement, the HHS FAR 52.249‑5 termination for convenience, the March 13 letter with nine preconditions, and Columbia’s March 21 announcement of an 18‑point anti‑discrimination plan. Background context includes the DOJ‑led Task Force to Combat Anti‑Semitism, the ED’s Title VI investigations, and Columbia’s prior development of anti‑discrimination measures.

The plaintiffs are represented by private counsel (Protect Democracy Project and Altshuler Berzon LLP).

evidence: On June 16, 2025, Judge Vyskocil denied the preliminary‑injunction motion and dismissed the case without prejudice for lack of standing for lack of standing. The court held that the unions could not force the Executive Branch to pay funds to a non‑party (Columbia) and failed to show any injury‑in‑fact to themselves or to members that was fairly traceable to defendants rather than to Columbia’s independent actions. The court found the unions’ alleged First Amendment chilling effects to be subjective and speculative, noted Columbia had represented it had planned its March 21 measures for months and did not simply implement the agencies’ demands, and observed that Columbia had committed to cover certain salaries previously supported by grants. The court also flagged that the Supreme Court’s recent stay in Department of Education v. California, 145 S. Ct. 966 (2025), suggests APA suits cannot be used to enforce contractual payment obligations, which are governed by the Tucker Act in the Court of Federal Claims, and remarked that money losses are ordinarily reparable and thus do not support preliminary injunctive relief.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: I identified the key factual basis as the suit filing, the executive order, the FHWA letter, the alleged freeze of NEVI funds, the background of the NEVI program, and the court's findings and injunction. I extracted these facts and collected supporting text snippets.

evidence: On May 7, 2025, sixteen states and the District of Columbia filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington challenging the U.S. Department of Transportation’s and the Federal Highway Administration’s actions that halted the National Electric Vehicle Infrastructure (NEVI) Formula Program.

On February 6, 2025, FHWA sent states a letter rescinding current and prior NEVI guidance, “suspending” approval of all state plans for all fiscal years, and barring any new obligations until new guidance issued and new plans were submitted and approved.
The states allege this action effectively frozen approximately $2.74 billion in unobligated NEVI funds and derailed state projects and procurements that had relied on prior approvals.
On January 20, 2025, the President issued Executive Order No. 14154 (“Unleashing American Energy”), directing agencies to immediately pause disbursement of IIJA and IRA funds, including NEVI.

Congress created the NEVI Formula Program in the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA), Pub. L. 117-58, appropriating $5 billion (FY 2022–2026), to “remain available until expended,” to fund states’ deployment and maintenance of EV charging infrastructure via a mandatory formula tied to Federal-Aid Highway apportionments.
FHWA issued NEVI program guidance in 2022 and updated it in 2023 and 2024; it approved state plans for FY 2022–2025 and advised that funds were “available for obligation.”

The Court found plaintiffs likely to succeed on their APA claims because DOT/FHWA exceeded IIJA’s statutory limits by categorically revoking state plan approvals and withholding funds without following IIJA’s procedures, and acted arbitrarily and capriciously by offering no reasoned explanation or consideration of alternatives and reliance interests.

The Court enjoined DOT and FHWA from (a) suspending or revoking— or maintaining any suspension or revocation of—previously approved State Electric Vehicle Infrastructure Deployment Plans of the following plaintiffs: Arizona, California, Colorado, Delaware, Hawaiʻi, Illinois, Maryland, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, Oregon, Rhode Island, Washington, and Wisconsin; and (b) withholding or withdrawing NEVI Formula Program funds for any such previously approved plans for any reason not set forth in IIJA or applicable FHWA regulations, or without following IIJA’s substantive and procedural requirements, including by refusing to review or process authorization requests to obligate funds.

States report canceled solicitations and contracts, inability to obligate or draw funds in the federal portal (codes marked “expired”), lost private partners and site hosts, and project delays that undermine state clean transportation, public health, and economic programs that Congress intended to support through NEVI.
extracted.value: The case involves sixteen states and the District of Columbia filing suit on May 7, 2025 in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington, challenging the Department of Transportation and the Federal Highway Administration for halting the National Electric Vehicle Infrastructure (NEVI) Formula Program. The suit alleges that a February 6, 2025 FHWA letter rescinded prior NEVI guidance, suspended all state plan approvals, and barred new obligations, effectively freezing approximately $2.74 billion in unobligated NEVI funds and derailing state projects and procurements that had relied on prior approvals. This action followed the President’s January 20, 2025 Executive Order No. 14154, which directed agencies to pause disbursement of IIJA and IRA funds, including NEVI. Congress authorized the NEVI program under the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act, appropriating $5 billion for FY 2022–2026 to fund EV charging infrastructure via a mandatory formula tied to Federal‑Aid Highway apportionments, and FHWA had issued and updated program guidance through 2024, approving state plans for FY 2022–2025 and indicating funds were available for obligation. The court found DOT/FHWA exceeded statutory limits and acted arbitrarily, granting a preliminary injunction preventing further suspension or revocation of approved plans and withholding of NEVI funds. The plaintiffs allege canceled solicitations, contract cancellations, inability to obligate funds, lost private partners, and project delays.

evidence: On May 7, 2025, sixteen states and the District of Columbia filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington challenging the U.S. Department of Transportation’s and the Federal Highway Administration’s actions that halted the National Electric Vehicle Infrastructure (NEVI) Formula Program.

The plaintiff states brought claims under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), 5 U.S.C. § 706(2), alleging agency action in excess of statutory authority, arbitrary and capricious action, and action not in accordance with law and without observance of procedures required by law; constitutional claims alleging violation of the separation of powers and the Take Care Clause; and a common law ultra vires claim. They sought declaratory and injunctive relief, including vacatur, to restore plan approvals and prevent withholding of NEVI funds except as permitted by IIJA; they also sought fees under 28 U.S.C. § 2412.

evidence: The plaintiff states moved for a preliminary injunction on May 7, 2025; the Court heard argument on June 17, 2025. On June 24, 2025, the Court granted the motion in part and denied it in part.

Relief: The Court enjoined DOT and FHWA from (a) suspending or revoking— or maintaining any suspension or revocation of—previously approved State Electric Vehicle Infrastructure Deployment Plans of the following plaintiffs: Arizona, California, Colorado, Delaware, Hawaiʻi, Illinois, Maryland, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, Oregon, Rhode Island, Washington, and Wisconsin; and (b) withholding or withdrawing NEVI Formula Program funds for any such previously approved plans for any reason not set forth in IIJA or applicable FHWA regulations, or without following IIJA’s substantive and procedural requirements, including by refusing to review or process authorization requests to obligate funds. The injunction was stayed for seven days to allow an appeal; defendants did not appeal, and the stay was lifted on July 2, 2025. The injunction remains in effect pending further order. The motion was denied as to the District of Columbia, Minnesota, and Vermont for lack of a sufficient evidentiary showing of irreparable harm at the preliminary injunction stage.
extracted.value: Motion for preliminary injunction filed by the plaintiff states on May 7, 2025, seeking an injunction to prevent DOT/FHWA from suspending or revoking approved NEVI plans and withholding funds; the Court partially granted the motion on June 24, 2025, enjoining DOT/FHWA from suspending/revoking approved plans and withholding funds for the listed states, but denied the motion for District of Columbia, Minnesota, and Vermont. The injunction was stayed for seven days and lifted on July 2, 2025.

evidence: Filed March 13, 2025, this suit in the Southern District of New York is brought by eight Columbia University and Barnard College students proceeding under pseudonyms.
Plaintiffs challenge two sets of government actions they say unlawfully chill their speech and associational rights regarding Palestine-related campus advocacy.

First, they target a February 13, 2025 letter from the House Committee requesting “all disciplinary records” concerning eleven specified Columbia incidents, asserting that, in context, it is an overbroad, viewpoint-based demand intended to expose and deter student speech (citing prior disclosures and an October 31, 2024 House report).

Key factual allegations include: prior House subpoenas to Columbia in 2024; a House staff report on October 31, 2024 summarizing disciplinary matters; doxing and harassment plaintiffs link to earlier disclosures; the February 13, 2025 House Committee letter requesting disciplinary records tied to eleven incidents (including the Hamilton Hall occupation); March 2025 announcements pausing/canceling Columbia’s federal funds; and a March 13, 2025 agency letter listing policy “preconditions” for continued funding. Plaintiffs allege Columbia has taken steps consistent with those demands (including discipline announcements, disciplinary system changes, a mask policy, and increased public safety authority), which they assert chills their speech and threatens associational privacy.
extracted.value: The case involves eight Columbia University and Barnard College students filing a lawsuit on March 13, 2025, challenging two sets of government actions that allegedly chill their speech and associational rights regarding Palestine‑related campus advocacy. The first action is a February 13, 2025 letter from the House Committee requesting all disciplinary records concerning eleven specified Columbia incidents, which plaintiffs assert is an overbroad, viewpoint‑based demand intended to expose and deter student speech. The second action is a March 13, 2025 joint letter from federal agencies setting preconditions for continued funding, including expulsions or multi‑year suspensions for encampment/Hamilton Hall cases, elimination of Columbia’s University Judicial Board and centralization of discipline, a mask ban, academic receivership of the Middle East, South Asian, and African Studies department, empowerment of campus law enforcement, and an IHRA‑aligned definition of antisemitism. Plaintiffs also point to prior House subpoenas in 2024, a House staff report on October 31, 2024 summarizing disciplinary matters, doxing and harassment linked to earlier disclosures, March 2025 announcements pausing or canceling federal funding, and Columbia’s steps consistent with the demands (discipline announcements, disciplinary system changes, a mask policy, and increased public safety authority) as evidence that these actions chill speech and threaten associational privacy.

evidence: On August 12, 2025, the court clarified the injunction’s scope to these components and programs: FDA’s CTP; the Office of Head Start and Head Start regional office staff; CDC’s National Center for HIV, Viral Hepatitis, STD, and Tuberculosis Prevention (NCHHSTP), Division of Reproductive Health (DRH), NIOSH, OSH, National Center for Environmental Health (NCEH), and National Center on Birth Defects and Developmental Disabilities (NCBDDD); and ASPE’s Division of Data and Technical Analysis (which updates the Federal Poverty Guidelines). The court reiterated the prohibition on further executing existing RIFs, issuing new RIFs, or placing additional employees on administrative leave within those identified components and programs, pending further order.

Order clarifying scope of injunction (Aug. 12, 2025) (ECF No. 89): enumerated covered CDC components, CTP, OHS and regional staff, and ASPE’s Division of Data and Technical Analysis; reiterated prohibition on executing/issuing RIFs or placing additional employees on leave within those programs.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: I identified the factual basis by locating statements that describe the events that triggered the lawsuit, the actions taken by HHS, and the alleged impact on programs. I extracted key excerpts that detail the March 27 announcement, the April 1 termination notices, the affected programs, and the states’ claims of unlawful effects.

evidence: HHS’s March 27, 2025 announcement to terminate approximately 10,000 HHS employees and reorganize the Department’s sub‑agencies and regional offices (the “March 27 Communiqué”).
On April 1, 2025, termination notices placed affected employees on administrative leave with terminations to take effect in June.

The States assert the RIF and reorganization halted or impaired CDC infectious‑disease labs, the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH), CDC’s Office on Smoking and Health (OSH), the FDA Center for Tobacco Products (CTP), the Office of Head Start (including regional support), and ASPE’s federal poverty guidelines work, among others.
They cite Secretary statements acknowledging anticipated “mistakes” and a deliberate decision to avoid “line‑by‑line” review due to speed and “political momentum.”
The States allege that HHS’s mass reduction‑in‑force (RIF) and reorganization unlawfully disable congressionally mandated programs and disregard appropriations.

Factual context centers on the administration’s workforce actions culminating in HHS’s March 27 plan to terminate about 10,000 employees, consolidate HHS’s divisions from 28 to 15, close five of ten regional offices, and create a new “Administration for a Healthy America.”
extracted.value: The case involves HHS's March 27, 2025 announcement to terminate roughly 10,000 employees, reorganize the department by consolidating its divisions from 28 to 15 and closing five of ten regional offices, and creating a new Administration for a Healthy America; the April 1 termination notices that placed employees on administrative leave; and the alleged impact of these actions on CDC infectious‑disease labs, NIOSH, OSH, FDA CTP, Head Start, and ASPE poverty‑guideline work, with the states asserting that the RIF and reorganization unlawfully disabled congressionally mandated programs and disregarded appropriations.

Note Important Filings.reasoning: I reviewed the summary and identified the procedural filings: complaint, motion for preliminary injunction, order granting the injunction, order denying the motion to vacate, order clarifying the scope, notice of appeal, and motion to dismiss. I extracted the parties, requests, and dates for each filing using the verbatim text provided.

evidence: On May 5, 2025, a coalition of nineteen states and the District of Columbia sued the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), its Secretary, and leaders of several HHS components in the U.S. District Court for the District of Rhode Island.

The States allege that HHS’s mass reduction‑in‑force (RIF) and reorganization unlawfully disable congressionally mandated programs and disregard appropriations. They bring claims under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), asserting the March 27 actions are final agency action that is arbitrary and capricious and contrary to law, and seek equitable relief for ultra vires conduct. They also allege constitutional violations of the separation of powers and the Appropriations Clause. Jurisdiction is invoked under 28 U.S.C. § 1331 and the APA (5 U.S.C. §§ 702, 704), with requests for declaratory and injunctive relief, vacatur under 5 U.S.C. § 706, a stay under § 705, and fees under the Equal Access to Justice Act.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: I identified the factual basis by extracting the timeline of AmeriCorps actions in April 2025, the impact on state-administered programs, the evidence presented in the complaint and record, and the statutory and procedural context that the plaintiffs claim was violated.

evidence: According to the complaint and record, AmeriCorps: (1) on April 15 ordered all National Civilian Community Corps (NCCC) members off assignment and onto administrative hold through April 30, to be exited from the program; (2) on April 16 placed about 85% of agency staff on administrative leave and, on April 24, began issuing reduction‑in‑force notices; and (3) on April 25 issued after‑hours termination letters to grant recipients nationwide, ending roughly 1,031 programs and about $396.5 million in funding, instructing immediate cessation of activities and directing that AmeriCorps members be exited for “compelling personal circumstances.”
The termination notices cited 2 C.F.R. § 200.340(a)(4).

The states allege these steps abruptly halted state‑administered service programs, removed AmeriCorps and VISTA members from service, and disrupted disaster relief, public health, education, veterans’ support, and conservation projects.

The plaintiffs assert: (i) claims under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), 5 U.S.C. §§ 701–706, that the actions were contrary to law, arbitrary and capricious, and taken without procedures required by law; (ii) a constitutional separation‑of‑powers claim (Article I’s power of the purse and the Article II Take Care Clause); and (iii) ultra vires action.

Central to the APA claims, the states rely on a rider Congress placed in AmeriCorps’s appropriation—incorporated for FY 2025 that "[the agency] shall make any significant changes to program requirements, service delivery or policy only through public notice and comment rulemaking." They also point to statutory safeguards for grant terminations, including notice and an opportunity to be heard, 42 U.S.C. § 12636.

Filed April 29, 2025 in the District of Maryland, this suit is brought by twenty‑four states and the District of Columbia, together with the Governors of Kentucky and Pennsylvania in their official capacities, against the federal national‑service agency (the Corporation for National and Community Service, operating as AmeriCorps) and the agency’s interim head.

The legal foundation and relief sought: The plaintiffs proceed under the APA, citing the FY 2024 Appropriations Act § 401 (as incorporated for FY 2025), 42 U.S.C. §§ 12501 et seq., 4950 et seq., and procedural protections in 42 U.S.C. § 12636; they also allege violations of the separation of powers and ultra vires action.
extracted.value: The case involves AmeriCorps taking a series of agency actions in April 2025: on April 15 it ordered all National Civilian Community Corps (NCCC) members off assignment and onto administrative hold through April 30; on April 16 it placed about 85% of agency staff on administrative leave and on April 24 began issuing reduction‑in‑force notices; and on April 25 it issued after‑hours termination letters to grant recipients nationwide, ending roughly 1,031 programs and about $396.5 million in funding, instructing immediate cessation of activities and directing AmeriCorps members to be exited for “compelling personal circumstances.” These actions abruptly halted state‑administered service programs, removed AmeriCorps and VISTA members from service, and disrupted disaster relief, public health, education, veterans’ support, and conservation projects. The case is supported by evidence from the complaint and record that the agency acted without required notice‑and‑comment rulemaking as mandated by a congressional appropriation rider and statutory safeguards for grant terminations (42 U.S.C. § 12636). Background information includes the suit filed on April 29, 2025 in the District of Maryland by twenty‑four states and the District of Columbia, the plaintiffs’ claims under the Administrative Procedure Act, constitutional separation‑of‑powers, and ultra vires action, and the statutory framework of the FY 2024 Appropriations Act § 401 (incorporated for FY 2025) and 42 U.S.C. §§ 12501 et seq., 4950 et seq.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: I reviewed the case summary, identified key factual events, actions, and context, and compiled them into a concise statement of the factual basis, supported by the relevant excerpts.

evidence: On April 7, 2025, two organizations—the American Library Association (a nonprofit membership association of libraries and librarians) and the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, AFL-CIO (a labor union representing library workers)—filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Institute of Museum and Library Services (IMLS), its Acting Director, the President, the Office of Management and Budget and its Director, and entities and officials associated with the U.S. Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE).

The case challenges implementation of a March 14, 2025 Executive Order entitled “Continuing the Reduction of the Federal Bureaucracy,” which directs IMLS and other identified entities to be “eliminated to the maximum extent consistent with applicable law,” to reduce their statutory functions and personnel to the minimum required by law, and to report to OMB what functions are statutorily required.

IMLS is an independent agency created by statute to support museum and library services nationwide, including mandatory duties to conduct research and data collection and to award specified grants, such as state formula grants, tribal and Native Hawaiian grants, and national leadership grants. Congress appropriated nearly $300 million to IMLS through September 30, 2025.

Plaintiffs allege that, following the Executive Order, DOGE personnel entered IMLS; on March 31, 2025, nearly all IMLS staff were placed on administrative leave and cut off from agency systems; on April 3, 2025, termination notices were issued to virtually all staff, retaining about a dozen; and on April 4, 2025, all 23 members of the National Museum and Library Services Board were removed.

Beginning April 1, 2025, IMLS began terminating grants, including state grants and two ALA grants, stating they were “no longer consistent with the agency’s priorities,” and citing the Executive Order.
Plaintiffs cite resulting harms, including service disruptions, temporary closure and layoffs at the Maine State Library, and cancellation of contracts for nationwide library data collection.

The complaint asserts six causes of action: (1) separation-of-powers (nonstatutory ultra vires) for unilaterally dismantling a congressionally created agency; (2) violation of the Take Care Clause; (3) Administrative Procedure Act (APA) § 706(2) claims that the actions are arbitrary and capricious, contrary to law (including alleged conflicts with the MLSA, appropriations, the Impoundment Control Act, and the Paperwork Reduction Act), and in excess of statutory authority; (4) APA § 706(1) to compel unlawfully withheld or unreasonably delayed mandatory action (e.g., awarding and disbursing grants and maintaining required data collections); (5) ultra vires; and (6) First Amendment (viewpoint discrimination tied to stated “patriotism” priorities).

Plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief, including orders to halt dissolution efforts, reinstate staff and the Board, reopen the agency and systems, restore grants and contracts, and require compliance with statutory mandates.

Judge Richard J. Leon presides. Plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction on April 10, 2025. After an April 30 hearing, the Court converted the motion to a TRO and, on May 1, 2025, entered a temporary restraining order (partly granting and partly denying relief) and later extended it to May 29, 2025 while supplemental briefing proceeded.
Defendants moved for reconsideration and submitted supplemental authority, including a D.C. Circuit stay order in a related USAGM case and a Supreme Court per curiam decision.

On June 6, 2025, the Court denied plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction without prejudice and denied defendants’ reconsideration motion as moot. In its memorandum opinion, the Court concluded plaintiffs had not shown a likelihood of success on the merits principally because the Court likely lacks subject‑matter jurisdiction over core aspects of the requested relief.

Relying on Department of Education v. California, 145 S. Ct. 966 (2025) (per curiam), and the D.C. Circuit’s ruling in Widakuswara v. Lake (USAGM), the Court held that claims effectively seeking specific performance of government grant agreements sound in contract and fall within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Court of Federal Claims under the Tucker Act, rather than the APA.
The Court also emphasized that plaintiffs’ request for broad, “wholesale” programmatic relief under the APA (to undo alleged agency dismantling) is not cognizable under APA review.
The Court therefore declined preliminary injunctive relief and denied a subsequent, narrower TRO motion as moot.
No trial has occurred, and no appeal is reflected on the docket.

On June 17, 2025, the Court set a merits schedule: defendants to produce the administrative record (filed July 15, 2025); plaintiffs’ summary judgment motion (extended to September 5, 2025); defendants’ combined opposition, cross‑motion, and motion to dismiss (due October 3, 2025); plaintiffs’ combined reply/response (due October 24, 2025); and defendants’ reply (due November 7, 2025).

Related proceedings referenced by the parties and the Court include Widakuswara v. Lake (D.C. Cir. orders addressing USAGM grant and personnel actions), Department of Education v. California (Supreme Court stay addressing grant terminations), and Rhode Island v. Trump (D.R.I. preliminary injunction addressing IMLS grants).

The record reflects plaintiffs’ factual allegations that IMLS staff were placed on administrative leave and later terminated, that the Board was removed, that multiple grants and contracts were terminated citing the Executive Order and “agency priorities,” and that libraries and grantees began experiencing immediate operational impacts.
extracted.value: The case involves the American Library Association and the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, AFL-CIO filing suit on April 7, 2025 against IMLS and related parties, challenging the March 14, 2025 Executive Order 'Continuing the Reduction of the Federal Bureaucracy'; plaintiffs allege that after the order DOGE personnel entered IMLS, staff were placed on administrative leave on March 31, 2025, terminated on April 3, 2025, and the Board was removed on April 4, 2025; IMLS began terminating grants starting April 1, 2025 citing the order, causing service disruptions, temporary closure and layoffs at the Maine State Library and cancellation of contracts for nationwide library data collection; plaintiffs assert six causes of action—separation-of-powers, Take Care Clause, APA §706(2) and §706(1) claims, ultra vires, First Amendment viewpoint discrimination—and seek declaratory and injunctive relief to halt the dismantling, reinstate staff and Board, reopen agency and systems, restore grants and contracts, and require compliance with statutory mandates; the court denied a preliminary injunction, citing lack of subject‑matter jurisdiction and referencing Department of Education v. California and Widakuswara v. Lake, and set a merits schedule on June 17, 2025.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: I identified the factual basis by extracting key events, evidence, and contextual background described in the case summary, focusing on the rapid construction of the detention facility, lack of NEPA compliance, documented environmental impacts, and the court’s findings.

evidence: Filed June 27, 2025, in the Southern District of Florida by two environmental nonprofits—Friends of the Everglades (a Florida 501(c)(3)) and the Center for Biological Diversity (a national 501(c)(3))—this suit challenges the rapid construction and use of a large immigration detention facility at the Dade‑Collier Training and Transition Airport (the “TNT” site) within the Big Cypress National Preserve.

Plaintiffs allege the defendants approved, funded, constructed, and are operating a detention and deportation center—publicly dubbed “Alligator Alcatraz”—for up to several thousand detainees at the TNT site without complying with the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA), 42 U.S.C. § 4321 et seq., and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), 5 U.S.C. § 701 et seq.

They assert the project’s location inside or adjacent to protected Everglades resources (including habitat for the Florida panther, Florida bonneted bat, Everglade snail kite, and wood stork) and within the footprint of the Western Everglades Restoration Plan creates significant environmental risks.

Evidence showed approximately 800,000 square feet of newly paved surfaces, installation of industrial‑style lighting, generator and waste systems, detainee housing and support facilities, ongoing ICE presence and inspections, and detainee transport and deportation activity at the site.

The court further held the absence of any NEPA Environmental Assessment or Environmental Impact Statement—coupled with the project’s rapid construction and operation—constituted final agency action reviewable under the APA.

As to irreparable harm, the court found ongoing and likely environmental harms—runoff and stormwater concerns from extensive new impervious surfaces in an interconnected, low‑nutrient wetland; increased sky brightness and noise affecting wildlife and recreation; impeded Tribe access; and species‑specific risks (e.g., to panthers and bonneted bats)—that cannot be redressed by money damages if the project expands pending review.
extracted.value: The case involves the rapid construction and use of a large immigration detention facility at the Dade‑Collier Training and Transition Airport (the TNT site) within the Big Cypress National Preserve, approved, funded, constructed, and operated by DHS/ICE, FDEM, and Miami‑Dade County without NEPA compliance; supported by evidence of approximately 800,000 square feet of newly paved surfaces, industrial‑style lighting, generator and waste systems, detainee housing and support facilities, ongoing ICE presence and inspections, and detainee transport and deportation activity at the site; with background information such as the project's location inside or adjacent to protected Everglades resources (habitat for the Florida panther, Florida bonneted bat, Everglade snail kite, and wood stork) and within the footprint of the Western Everglades Restoration Plan, the court's findings of major federal action, absence of any NEPA Environmental Assessment or Environmental Impact Statement, and irreparable environmental harms including runoff, stormwater concerns, increased sky brightness and noise, impeded Tribe access, and species‑specific risks.

evidence: On August 21, 2025, the court issued an 82‑page Omnibus Order granting in part and denying in part preliminary injunctive relief and denying the State and Federal Defendants’ venue challenges.

- Prohibits the State and Federal Defendants, and those acting in concert with them (including contractors), from installing any additional industrial‑style lighting, or doing any paving, filling, excavating, fencing, or other site expansion (including new buildings, tents, dormitories, or administrative facilities) at TNT.
- Prohibits bringing any additional persons onto the TNT site who were not already detained there when the order took effect.
- Permits modifications or repairs to existing facilities solely to increase safety or mitigate environmental or other risks.

- Requires removal, within 60 days (as population attrition allows safe implementation), of temporary fencing installed for the detention project, the industrial “Sunbelt” lighting and any additional lighting installed for detention use, and generators, gas, sewage, and other waste and receptacles installed to support the project.
- Sets a $100 bond.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: I identified the factual basis by locating the chronological federal actions, the letters, freezes, and terminations, and the subsequent research disruptions and policy changes. These are the key facts upon which the plaintiffs base their claims.

evidence: On March 31, 2025, HHS, ED, and GSA announced a “comprehensive review” of Harvard’s federal contracts and grants because of alleged failures to protect Jewish students, referencing more than $255.6 million in grants and $8.7 billion in multi‑year commitments.

On April 3, 2025, the Task Force sent Harvard a letter outlining “preconditions” to remain a federal grantee, including: overhauling student discipline with senior‑leader control; a “comprehensive mask ban”; shuttering all DEI programs; adopting “merit‑based” admissions and hiring; auditing and expanding “viewpoint diversity” department‑by‑department; and governance and leadership changes.

A second letter on April 11 demanded further measures, such as federal audits of admissions and hiring through at least 2028, immediate reporting to DHS of foreign students who commit conduct violations, sanctions for faculty found to have discriminated, annual “viewpoint diversity” audits and hiring or admissions to create a “critical mass” of diverse viewpoints, and periodic certified reports to the government.

Harvard responded on April 14, 2025, stating it would not accept the government’s conditions, asserting they contravened the First Amendment and statutory procedures. Hours later, HHS/ED/GSA announced a freeze of $2.2 billion in multi‑year grants and $60 million in contracts to Harvard.

On May 5, 2025, the Secretary of Education sent Harvard a letter declaring Harvard should “no longer seek GRANTS” because “none will be provided,” citing generalized concerns about discrimination and governance and referencing the earlier demands.
Then, on May 6, 2025, NIH notified Harvard of the termination of roughly $2.2 billion in NIH awards (658 grants).
Between May 9 and May 12, 2025, USDA, DOE, DOD, NSF, and HUD sent additional letters terminating awards (collectively totaling approximately $2.7 billion, including the NIH terminations).

The agencies’ administrative records, as described by Plaintiffs, do not include formal Title VI findings, pre‑termination notices or hearings, or congressional reports tied to termination, and several letters do not explain how specific awards failed to further agency program goals beyond the generalized civil‑rights allegations.

Plaintiffs’ factual submissions describe widespread research disruptions and layoffs at Harvard following the freeze and terminations, including halted clinical studies, loss of unique data and biospecimens, layoffs or furloughs, and student and postdoctoral funding losses.

They also recount instances where Harvard altered campus policies after the government demands (e.g., centralized student discipline for cross‑school cases; the closing or renaming of DEI offices and withdrawal of funding for certain affinity celebrations), and attest to a chilling effect on faculty and student speech and research in areas perceived as disfavored by the government.

On April 11, 2025, two faculty organizations sued in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts—later joined by a labor union representing Harvard academic workers—challenging federal actions that threatened and then cut off billions in federal research funds to Harvard University.
extracted.value: The case involves a lawsuit filed on April 11, 2025 by two faculty organizations and later joined by a labor union, challenging federal actions that threatened and then cut off billions in federal research funds to Harvard University, and a series of federal actions in 2025—including a March 31 comprehensive review of Harvard’s federal contracts and grants, letters from the Task Force on April 3 and April 11 demanding preconditions and additional measures, a freeze of $2.2 billion in multi‑year grants and $60 million in contracts, and subsequent terminations by NIH and other agencies totalling roughly $2.7 billion—supported by the relevant letters, freezes, and terminations— with background information such as the lack of formal Title VI findings, pre‑termination notices, congressional reports, and the widespread impact on research and campus policies.

Plaintiffs challenge OJP’s April 2025 termination—via identical email notices—of more than 370 multi‑year DOJ/OJP grants and cooperative agreements totaling over $820 million.

OJP invoked 2 C.F.R. § 200.340(a)(4), stating each award “no longer effectuates the program goals or agency priorities,” and asserted changed Department priorities (e.g., directly supporting law enforcement, combatting violent crime, protecting children, supporting victims of trafficking/sexual assault, and improving law enforcement coordination).
The notices directed immediate cessation of work, limited reimbursement to pre‑termination costs, and allowed a 30‑day administrative appeal.

Plaintiffs alleged no prior individualized notice or explanation, unreimbursed expenses at the time of cut‑off, and abrupt program shutdowns affecting, among others, community violence intervention, victim services (including sign language interpretation for Deaf victims), behavioral health crisis response planning, and prosecutor diversion initiatives.

OJP’s declaration stated DOJ/OJP leadership conducted a multi‑month, individualized review of awards and terminated 376 awards out of more than 11,000 open awards; 139 appeals were filed, and some terminations had been reversed on appeal.

The factual basis: Plaintiffs allege OJP summarily terminated hundreds of multi‑year public‑safety awards across domains (violence prevention/intervention, victims’ services, juvenile justice, substance use and mental health, reentry, and research), using one boilerplate rationale tied to changed agency priorities, without individualized reasoning or pre‑deprivation process.

Plaintiffs asserted claims under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) (5 U.S.C. § 706): (1) arbitrary and capricious agency action for en masse terminations with only boilerplate justifications and (2) action contrary to law because § 200.340 requires termination authority to be clearly specified in the award’s terms and (they contend) does not permit post‑award priority changes to justify termination.

Constitutional claims alleged violations of the Fifth Amendment’s Due Process Clause (lack of pre‑deprivation process; vagueness) and violations of the separation of powers, the Spending and Appropriations Clauses, and the Take Care Clause (asserting an Executive refusal to spend appropriated funds).
Plaintiffs also pleaded an equitable ultra vires claim.
Plaintiffs are represented by the Democracy Forward Foundation (public-interest counsel) and Perry Law (private counsel). The DOJ Civil Division, Federal Programs Branch, represents Defendants.
extracted.value: The case involves five nonprofit organizations filing a class action on May 21, 2025, challenging the U.S. Department of Justice Office of Justice Programs’ April 2025 termination of more than 370 multi‑year DOJ/OJP grants and cooperative agreements totaling over $820 million. The terminations were carried out via identical email notices citing 2 C.F.R. § 200.340(a)(4) that the awards no longer effectuates the program goals or agency priorities, and referencing changed Department priorities such as directly supporting law enforcement, combatting violent crime, protecting children, supporting victims of trafficking/sexual assault, and improving law enforcement coordination. The notices required immediate cessation of work, limited reimbursement to pre‑termination costs, and allowed a 30‑day administrative appeal. Plaintiffs alleged no prior individualized notice or explanation, unreimbursed expenses at the cut‑off, and abrupt program shutdowns affecting community violence intervention, victim services (including sign language interpretation for Deaf victims), behavioral health crisis response planning, and prosecutor diversion initiatives. The evidence includes the identical email termination notices, OJP’s declaration of a multi‑month individualized review of awards, the number of terminated awards (376 of more than 11,000), the number of appeals (139), and that some terminations had been reversed on appeal. Background information includes OJP’s invocation of 2 C.F.R. § 200.340(a)(4), the asserted changed Department priorities, and the fact that the plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief under the APA and the Fifth Amendment due process, separation of powers, Spending and Appropriations Clauses, and the Take Care Clause.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: I identified key factual events and supporting evidence from the case summary and extracted them into a concise statement that captures the issuance of the executive order, the lawsuit and TRO, the summary judgment and injunction, and the contextual background.

evidence: On April 9, 2025, the President issued Executive Order 14,263, “Addressing Risks from Susman Godfrey,” targeting a private litigation firm based on its clients and advocacy—especially work defending the integrity of the 2020 election and alleged “DEI” practices.

The firm filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia on April 11, 2025, against the United States, the Executive Office of the President, numerous federal departments and agencies, and their heads (all in their official capacities).

On April 14, it moved for a temporary restraining order (TRO). On April 15, Judge Loren L. AliKhan granted a TRO enjoining enforcement of Sections 1, 3, and 5 of the order, and on April 16 extended the TRO by agreement through final judgment.

On June 27, 2025, the court denied the government’s motion to dismiss, granted the firm’s motion for summary judgment on Counts I–IV and VI–IX, declared Executive Order 14,263 unconstitutional and “null and void,” and entered a permanent injunction.

The permanent injunction: (1) bars implementation or enforcement of Executive Order 14,263 in any manner; (2) prohibits reliance on Section 1’s statements; (3) directs DOJ and the Attorney General to circulate the order to all affected agencies and certify compliance; (4) requires rescission of all formal or informal guidance implementing the order; (5) requires withdrawal of any disclosure requests issued under Section 3(a) and cessation of any future requests; (6) requires cessation of any security‑clearance reviews undertaken pursuant to the order and reversal of any suspensions; (7) orders OMB to reverse any cessation of material or services previously provided to the firm under Section 2(b); (8) requires DOJ and EEOC to cease any investigations of the firm made pursuant to Section 4 and to withdraw any information requests; and (9) directs all agencies to take any additional steps necessary to unwind or prevent implementation of the order.

The court’s ruling followed similar outcomes in related cases enjoining materially similar executive orders against other law firms: Perkins Coie LLP v. U.S. Department of Justice, 2025 WL 1276857 (D.D.C. May 2, 2025); Jenner & Block LLP v. U.S. Department of Justice, 2025 WL 1482021 (D.D.C. May 23, 2025); and Wilmer Cutler Pickering Hale & Dorr LLP v. Executive Office of the President, 2025 WL 1502329 (D.D.C. May 27, 2025).

The court held that the order violated the First Amendment by retaliating against the firm for protected advocacy and by engaging in viewpoint discrimination; violated the Petition Clause by restricting the firm’s ability to access courts and agencies; infringed freedom of association by compelling contractor disclosures designed to chill association; and violated the Fifth Amendment by depriving the firm of protected liberty and property interests without due process, by being impermissibly vague (especially through standardless “national interest” and “interests of the United States” triggers), by denying clients’ due‑process right to counsel of choice, and by denying equal protection as a class‑of‑one with no rational basis.
extracted.value: The case involves the President issuing Executive Order 14,263 on April 9, 2025 targeting a private litigation firm; the firm filed suit on April 11, 2025, obtained a temporary restraining order on April 15, 2025; the court granted summary judgment and a permanent injunction on June 27, 2025, declaring the order unconstitutional and null, and requiring rescission of enforcement and various rescissions; these facts are supported by the order’s contents, the court filings, and the injunction text, with background information such as the similarity to prior cases enjoining executive orders against other law firms and the court’s constitutional analysis.
