evidence: The firm filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia on April 11, 2025, against the United States, the Executive Office of the President, numerous federal departments and agencies, and their heads (all in their official capacities). It brought constitutional claims under the First and Fifth Amendments and a separation-of-powers/ultra vires claim, and sought declaratory and injunctive relief. The firm was represented by private counsel (Munger, Tolles & Olson LLP). On April 14, it moved for a temporary restraining order (TRO). On April 15, Judge Loren L. AliKhan granted a TRO enjoining enforcement of Sections 1, 3, and 5 of the order, and on April 16 extended the TRO by agreement through final judgment. The firm moved for summary judgment on April 23; the government moved to dismiss the same day. The court held argument on May 8. An amended complaint filed on May 9 added additional federal defendants; the government renewed its motion to dismiss on May 12; the firm renewed its summary-judgment motion.

On June 27, 2025, the court denied the government’s motion to dismiss, granted the firm’s motion for summary judgment on Counts I–IV and VI–IX, declared Executive Order 14,263 unconstitutional and “null and void,” and entered a permanent injunction. The court held that the order violated the First Amendment by retaliating against the firm for protected advocacy and by engaging in viewpoint discrimination; violated the Petition Clause by restricting the firm’s ability to access courts and agencies; infringed freedom of association by compelling contractor disclosures designed to chill association; and violated the Fifth Amendment by depriving the firm of protected liberty and property interests without due process, by being impermissibly vague (especially through standardless “national interest” and “interests of the United States” triggers), by denying clients’ due-process right to counsel of choice, and by denying equal protection as a class-of-one with no rational basis. The court also concluded the order lacked statutory or constitutional authority and intruded on judicial functions, but it entered judgment on Counts I–IV and VI–IX. See Mem. Op. (D.D.C. June 27, 2025) (ECF No. 206); Order (ECF No. 207).

The permanent injunction: (1) bars implementation or enforcement of Executive Order 14,263 in any manner; (2) prohibits reliance on Section 1’s statements; (3) directs DOJ and the Attorney General to circulate the order to all affected agencies and certify compliance; (4) requires rescission of all formal or informal guidance implementing the order; (5) requires withdrawal of any disclosure requests issued under Section 3(a) and cessation of any future requests; (6) requires cessation of any security-clearance reviews undertaken pursuant to the order and reversal of any suspensions; (7) orders OMB to reverse any cessation of material or services previously provided to the firm under Section 2(b); (8) requires DOJ and EEOC to cease any investigations of the firm made pursuant to Section 4 and to withdraw any information requests; and (9) directs all agencies to take any additional steps necessary to unwind or prevent implementation of the order. The judgment is final; no trial occurred and no appeal is noted in the record.
extracted.value: Susman Godfrey LLP v. United States (District of Columbia, 2025). Filing date: April 11, 2025. Motions: TRO filed April 14, granted April 15, extended April 16; summary judgment filed April 23, government moved to dismiss same day. Argument held May 8. Amended complaint filed May 9; government renewed motion to dismiss May 12; firm renewed its summary-judgment motion. Final ruling on June 27, 2025: denied the government’s motion to dismiss, granted summary judgment on Counts I–IV and VI–IX, declared Executive Order 14,263 unconstitutional, entered permanent injunction (bars implementation or enforcement of Executive Order 14,263; prohibits reliance on Section 1’s statements; directs DOJ and the Attorney General to circulate the order to all affected agencies and certify compliance; requires rescission of all formal or informal guidance implementing the order; requires withdrawal of any disclosure requests issued under Section 3(a) and cessation of any future requests; requires cessation of any security‑clearance reviews undertaken pursuant to the order and reversal of any suspensions; orders OMB to reverse any cessation of material or services previously provided to the firm under Section 2(b); requires DOJ and EEOC to cease any investigations of the firm made pursuant to Section 4 and to withdraw any information requests; directs all agencies to take any additional steps necessary to unwind or prevent implementation of the order). The court also concluded the order lacked statutory or constitutional authority and intruded on judicial functions, but it entered judgment on Counts I–IV and VI–IX. Judgment final; no trial occurred; no appeal noted.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: I identified the factual basis by locating the summary's descriptions of the contested actions—board removals, presidency changes, forcible takeover, staff termination, and asset transfer—along with the supporting evidence such as the executive order, termination emails, DOGE involvement, and the asset transfer to GSA. I extracted these verbatim snippets and summarized the facts.

evidence: the Administration’s effort to dismantle the United States Institute of Peace (USIP), a congressionally established “independent nonprofit corporation.”
the President’s March 14, 2025 mass removal of all twelve appointed Board members without meeting the statutory conditions in 22 U.S.C. § 4605(f);

actions by the three ex officio Board members (the Secretaries of State and Defense and the President of the National Defense University) to remove Acting President Ambassador George E. Moose and install first Kenneth Jackson and then Nate Cavanaugh as USIP president;
a forcible takeover of USIP’s headquarters orchestrated by personnel from the U.S. “DOGE” Service and law enforcement;
the subsequent firing of nearly all USIP staff;
transfers of USIP’s building and other assets to the General Services Administration (GSA).

After Executive Order 14217 (Feb. 19, 2025) directed elimination of “non‑statutory components and functions” and reduction of statutory functions to minimum levels, White House personnel emailed termination notices to all twelve appointed USIP Board members on March 14 without invoking § 4605(f).
The three ex officio Board members purported to remove Moose and to install Jackson, later replaced by Cavanaugh.

On March 17, DOGE personnel, with assistance from law enforcement, took control of USIP’s headquarters; plaintiffs’ counsel and staff were escorted out; USIP systems access was taken; and records and insignia were disturbed.
Nearly all staff were later terminated, and USIP’s headquarters and other assets were transferred to GSA without consideration.
extracted.value: The case involves the President’s March 14, 2025 removal of all twelve appointed USIP Board members without following statutory removal procedures, the ex officio Board members’ removal of Acting President George E. Moose and appointment of Kenneth Jackson and later Nate Cavanaugh as president, a forcible takeover of USIP headquarters by DOGE and law enforcement on March 17, the subsequent firing of nearly all USIP staff, and the transfer of USIP’s building and other assets to the General Services Administration, all of which are supported by Executive Order 14217, termination emails, DOGE actions, staff termination records, and asset transfer documents.

evidence: On an expedited merits schedule, plaintiffs moved for summary judgment on April 5; defendants cross‑moved April 11. After a May 14 hearing, the court (Judge Beryl A. Howell) issued a detailed memorandum opinion and order on May 19, 2025, granting plaintiffs’ motion and denying defendants’ cross‑motion. Reported at 2025 WL 1428641, the opinion held: (1) USIP is part of the federal government for separation‑of‑powers purposes but is not part of the Executive Branch and does not wield Article II executive power; (2) the President therefore lacked constitutional authority to ignore 22 U.S.C. § 4605(f)’s limited removal mechanisms for appointed Board members; and (3) even if USIP were within the Executive Branch, the Board’s multimember, bipartisan, expert structure and its de minimis, if any, executive power brought it within Humphrey’s Executor and its progeny, so the USIP Act’s removal protections were constitutional. The court declared the President’s removal of the twelve appointed Board members unlawful, null, and void; declared the ex officio members’ removal of Moose and the appointments of Jackson and Cavanaugh as USIP president invalid; declared that Moose remains USIP’s president and may be removed only by a duly constituted Board under § 4606; declared all actions taken or authorized by Jackson or Cavanaugh as acting presidents invalid; and declared void the transfer of USIP’s headquarters and other assets to GSA and the appointment of an Endowment officer to move Endowment funds. The court permanently enjoined defendants (other than ex officio Board members acting within their board roles) from trespassing on USIP property; from maintaining, gaining, or exercising access or control over USIP offices, facilities, systems, records, or resources; from acting or purporting to act in USIP’s name; and from using USIP’s name, emblem, seal, or other marks. It further enjoined the ex officio Board members from unilaterally transferring any USIP assets without Board majority consent. No bond was required.
extracted.value: Summary judgment granted to plaintiffs on May 19, 2025; defendants’ cross‑motions denied. Court declared President’s removal unlawful, ex officio removal invalid, Moose remains president, actions by Jackson/Cavanaugh invalid, transfer to GSA void; permanently enjoined defendants from trespassing, controlling, or acting in USIP’s name; enjoined ex officio members from unilateral asset transfers.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: Reviewed the summary for events, evidence, and background facts that constitute the case's factual basis; extracted key statements that describe the EPA’s termination attempt, Citibank’s refusal, the grant awards, the legal filings, and the court's injunction.

evidence: This consolidated action in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia challenges the Environmental Protection Agency’s March 2025 attempt to terminate billions of dollars in previously awarded clean‑energy grants under the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund (GGRF), as well as Citibank’s refusal to disburse grant funds.

The lead case was filed March 8, 2025, by Climate United Fund, a nonprofit NCIF grantee, against Citibank, N.A.; the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA); and EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin, in his official capacity.

Congress, through the Inflation Reduction Act, appropriated $27 billion for the GGRF, including approximately $14 billion for the National Clean Investment Fund (NCIF), to be awarded competitively to nonprofit financing entities.
In April 2024 EPA awarded NCIF grants to Climate United ($6.97 billion), CGC ($5 billion), and PFC ($2 billion).

Citibank stopped honoring disbursement requests beginning in mid‑February 2025 after receiving an FBI “freeze” recommendation, followed by Treasury’s March 4 directive to pause disbursements and EPA’s March 10 instruction to continue the pause, even though EPA had not issued any Notice of Exclusive Control under the ACAs.

On March 11, 2025, EPA sent notices purporting to terminate all NCIF and related CCIA grant agreements effective immediately, citing concerns about program integrity, “waste, fraud, and abuse,” misalignment with agency priorities, and insufficient oversight.
Plaintiffs claim they were given no notice or opportunity to be heard and that EPA did not identify credible evidence of misconduct or any breach of grant conditions.

Judge Tanya S. Chutkan granted interim relief and then a preliminary injunction. On March 18, 2025, the court granted in part a temporary restraining order, enjoining EPA and Citibank from giving effect to the termination letters and preserving the status quo by prohibiting transfer or re‑obligation of the grant funds while not yet compelling disbursements.

The April 15 order (with a memorandum opinion filed April 16) enjoined EPA from effectuating the March 11 termination notices; from issuing any Notice of Exclusive Control or otherwise limiting access to funds except as permitted by the ACAs, the grant awards, applicable regulations, and law; and from directly or indirectly causing Citibank to deny, obstruct, delay, or limit access to the grant accounts.
extracted.value: The case involves EPA’s March 2025 attempt to terminate billions of dollars in previously awarded clean‑energy grants under the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund (GGRF) and Citibank’s refusal to disburse grant funds, supported by the lead complaint filed March 8, 2025 by Climate United Fund against Citibank, N.A.; EPA; and EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin, the appropriation of $27 billion for the GGRF under the Inflation Reduction Act, the April 2024 awards of $6.97 billion to Climate United, $5 billion to CGC, and $2 billion to PFC, the mid‑February 2025 suspension of disbursements following an FBI “freeze” recommendation and Treasury’s March 4 directive, EPA’s March 11 termination notices citing concerns about program integrity and “waste, fraud, and abuse,” the plaintiffs’ claim of lack of notice and due process, and the court’s preliminary injunction on April 15, 2025 enjoining EPA and Citibank from effectuating the termination notices and restricting transfer of funds.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: I identified the key factual elements by locating the statements that describe the parties, the executive orders challenged, the specific provisions, the agency actions alleged to be caused by those orders, the evidence cited by the plaintiffs, and the court’s denial of a preliminary injunction. evidence: Filed on February 19, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, this case challenges three presidential executive orders issued January 20–21, 2025: Executive Order 14151 (Ending Radical and Wasteful Government DEI Programs and Preferencing), Executive Order 14168 (Defending Women From Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government), and Executive Order 14173 (Ending Illegal Discrimination and Restoring Merit‑Based Opportunity).

The plaintiffs are two nonprofit organizations—the National Urban League and the AIDS Foundation of Chicago that receive and administer federal grants and contracts supporting services for underserved communities.

The challenged provisions include: (1) EO 14151’s Equity Termination Provision directing agencies to terminate “equity‑related” grants and contracts, and its List Provision instructing agencies to list grantees that advanced DEI/DEIA or environmental justice since January 20, 2021; (2) EO 14173’s Certification Provision requiring every federal contract and grant to include a certification that the counterparty “does not operate any programs promoting DEI that violate any applicable Federal anti‑discrimination laws” and an FCA‑materiality clause, its Contract Terms Provision directing removal of references to DEI/DEIA “principles” from federal acquisition/grant procedures, its Government Mandates Provision to terminate “diversity,” “equity,” and like mandates, and its Report Provision directing DOJ to identify sectors, “the most egregious and discriminatory DEI practitioners,” and up to nine potential civil compliance investigations per agency; and (3) EO 14168’s Gender Funding Termination Provision and Promoting Gender Ideology Provision barring use of federal funds to “promote gender ideology” and directing agencies to end federal funding of “gender ideology.”

The Urban League specifically alleges EPA suspended on March 12, 2025, and then terminated on May 1, 2025, a $500,000 “Urban Environmental Justice Collaborative Program” grant, citing alignment with agency policy emphasizing “merit, fairness, and excellence.” The Urban League also reports a DOL direction on February 12, 2025, not to address “equity” in quarterly reporting.

The AIDS Foundation alleges that HRSA and HUD instructions tied to the Anti‑Gender Order required removal or alteration of terms such as “gender identity,” “gender‑affirming care,” and “LGBTQIA” in program materials and reporting forms, and that Chicago (as a pass‑through recipient) relayed CDC/HHS directives to terminate DEI‑related activities under certain awards.

Plaintiffs allege the orders and agency memoranda implementing them spurred “stop‑work” notices, reporting restrictions, data‑collection changes, and terminations affecting DEI‑or equity‑related activities.
On May 2, 2025, the Court denied plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction. In a detailed memorandum opinion, the Court held plaintiffs had not shown a likelihood of success on the merits.

As to standing, the Court found plaintiffs likely lacked standing to challenge some intra‑governmental directives (e.g., the List Provision and the Report Provision) and had not yet shown standing as to others (e.g., the “Contract Terms” and “Government Mandates” provisions).

The court concluded plaintiffs likely had standing to challenge the “funding‑focused” provisions (EO 14151’s Equity Termination Provision; EO 14168’s Gender Funding Termination and Promoting Gender Ideology provisions) and EO 14173’s Certification Provision.
On June 30, 2025, plaintiffs filed a First Amended and Supplemental Complaint.
extracted.value: The case involves the National Urban League and the AIDS Foundation of Chicago challenging three presidential executive orders issued on January 20–21, 2025 that seek to eliminate DEI programs and gender‑ideology funding. The plaintiffs allege that the orders—specifically EO 14151’s Equity Termination Provision, EO 14168’s Gender Funding Termination Provision, and EO 14173’s Certification Provision—led to agency actions such as EPA suspending and terminating a $500,000 grant, a DOL directive to omit equity from quarterly reporting, and HRSA/HUD instructions to remove terms like “gender identity” and “LGBTQIA” from program materials. They cite stop‑work notices, reporting restrictions, data‑collection changes, and terminations as evidence that the orders have chilled speech and constrained services. The case is supported by evidence of agency memoranda implementing the orders and a denial of a preliminary injunction on May 2, 2025 due to lack of standing and likelihood of success.

evidence: On February 28, 2025, plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction. The Court (Judge Timothy J. Kelly) set argument for March 19, 2025.

A nonprofit, Do No Harm, moved to intervene as a defendant; on March 12, 2025, the Court denied intervention without prejudice, permitting Do No Harm to participate as amicus and present argument at the preliminary‑injunction hearing.
On May 2, 2025, the Court denied plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction. In a detailed memorandum opinion, the Court held plaintiffs had not shown a likelihood of success on the merits.

As to standing, the Court found plaintiffs likely lacked standing to challenge some intra‑governmental directives (e.g., the List Provision and the Report Provision) and had not yet shown standing as to others (e.g., the “Contract Terms” and “Government Mandates” provisions). The Court concluded plaintiffs likely had standing to challenge the “funding‑focused” provisions (EO 14151’s Equity Termination Provision; EO 14168’s Gender Funding Termination and Promoting Gender Ideology provisions) and EO 14173’s Certification Provision.

On the merits, the Court treated plaintiffs’ challenges as facial and held they were unlikely to prevail on their Fifth Amendment vagueness claims (particularly given the government’s role as funder/contracting party) or First Amendment claims. The Court reasoned that the funding provisions regulate what the government will fund, not private speech outside the scope of the grants, and that the Certification Provision’s reference to DEI programs that violate federal anti‑discrimination laws does not restrict any First Amendment right to engage in unlawful discrimination.
The Court denied the preliminary injunction without reaching the remaining factors, and noted that as‑applied challenges to specific enforcement actions might present different issues later.
extracted.value: Preliminary injunction hearing set for March 19, 2025, following plaintiffs’ motion filed February 28, 2025. Do No Harm moved to intervene on March 12, 2025, but the Court denied intervention without prejudice and allowed amicus participation. On May 2, 2025, the Court denied the preliminary injunction, holding plaintiffs lacked likelihood of success on the merits and had standing issues for many challenged provisions, though they had standing for the funding‑focused provisions. The decision was based on facial challenges and First/Fifth Amendment claims, and the Court noted that as‑applied challenges may present different issues.

evidence: The plaintiffs bring two claims: (i) a constitutional claim that the coordinated actions—mass separations of probationers, large‑scale RIF preparations, and the deferred resignation program—violate separation‑of‑powers principles by undermining Congress’s authority to create, fund, and staff agencies and to set their missions; and (ii) an Administrative Procedure Act claim alleging that defendants are directing and implementing RIFs contrary to statute and OPM regulations, including by initiating RIFs for impermissible reasons, failing to establish proper competitive areas, and disregarding legally required retention factors and notice. Statutory bases cited include 5 U.S.C. § 3502 and 5 C.F.R. Part 351.

evidence: On February 12, 2025, several federal-employee unions filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the President and multiple federal officials and agency leaders. The plaintiffs—the National Treasury Employees Union (NTEU), the National Federation of Federal Employees (NFFE), the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers (IAM), the International Federation of Professional and Technical Engineers (IFPTE), and the International Union, United Automobile, Aerospace and Agricultural Implement Workers of America (UAW)—challenge a series of executive-branch actions they allege are intended to drastically shrink the civil service: (1) a January 20, 2025 OPM directive requiring agencies to identify and promptly decide whether to retain probationary employees; (2) OPM’s January 28, 2025 “Fork in the Road” deferred resignation program; and (3) Executive Order No. 14210 (Feb. 11, 2025), which directs agency heads to “promptly undertake preparations to initiate large-scale reductions in force,” prioritizing, among other areas, non‑statutorily mandated functions, offices not deemed “essential” during a lapse in appropriations, and initiatives the administration suspends or closes.

The unions seek declaratory and injunctive relief halting implementation of Section 3(c) of EO 14210, preventing agency terminations of probationary employees under the OPM directive, and enjoining OPM from extending or replicating the deferred resignation program, along with fees and costs.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: I identified the factual basis by extracting key events, plaintiffs' allegations, court orders, and supporting evidence directly quoted from the case summary, ensuring no assumptions or additions were made.

evidence: Filed on February 11, 2025, this action challenges the Executive Branch’s suspension and termination of U.S. foreign‑assistance funding and programs following President Trump’s January 20, 2025 Executive Order 14169, “Reevaluating and Realigning United States Foreign Aid.”

The plaintiffs are U.S. nonprofits and companies that implement State Department and USAID foreign‑aid awards (including a trade association for small implementers); they are represented by private counsel.

Relying on the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), the Impoundment Control Act (ICA), the Anti‑Deficiency Act and Purpose Act, and the Constitution, plaintiffs allege that the government unlawfully froze obligations and disbursements, issued stop‑work orders, and then mass‑terminated thousands of foreign‑aid awards—actions they say ignored Congress’s 2024 appropriations for foreign assistance and the statutory limits on impoundment.

Within days of filing, plaintiffs moved for a TRO/preliminary injunction. On February 13, 2025, Judge Amir H. Ali (D.D.C.) granted a TRO in both this case and the related case AIDS Vaccine Advocacy Coalition v. U.S. Department of State (No. 25‑cv‑400), enjoining implementation of the State/USAID pause directives and forbidding the suspension, pausing, or other prevention of obligation or disbursement for awards in existence as of January 19, 2025, and enjoining the issuance or enforcement of terminations, suspensions, or stop‑work orders as to those awards.
The Court later enforced the TRO on February 25, 2025, ordering defendants to pay invoices and honor letter‑of‑credit drawdowns for work completed before February 13.

After a consolidated preliminary‑injunction hearing, the Court on March 10, 2025, granted a preliminary injunction in part. The Court held plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their APA challenge to the initial blanket suspension of funds (January 20–February 13) and on their constitutional separation‑of‑powers claim that the Executive had unlawfully impounded congressionally appropriated funds without following the ICA, and that the asserted foreign‑affairs authority could not override Congress’s exclusive power of the purse.

The Court enjoined (1) giving effect to any terminations, suspensions, or stop‑work orders issued between January 20 and February 13, 2025; (2) withholding of payments or LOC drawdowns for work completed before February 13; and (3) unlawful impoundment, directing defendants to make available for obligation the full amount of foreign‑assistance funds appropriated in the 2024 Act.

On April 22, 2025, plaintiffs filed a First Amended Complaint expanding their claims. They allege the State Department and USAID executed “tranches” of mass terminations based on cursory spreadsheets and action memoranda signed by the Secretary, constituting pretextual, post hoc rationalizations for the earlier freeze; that the agencies are moving to retire USAID’s independent operations and shift or eliminate programs; and that defendants’ decisions to “shut down” congressionally mandated programs and to hold funds in reserve violate the ICA, Anti‑Deficiency Act, Purpose Act, and the 2024 Appropriations Act.

Factual context: The record shows that, after Executive Order 14169, State and USAID paused obligations and disbursements and issued stop‑work orders, in some instances halting payment even for completed work. OMB issued a government‑wide pause memorandum (M‑25‑13) that was later enjoined in separate litigation. Within weeks, State and USAID announced tens of hundreds of suspensions and terminations. Plaintiffs submitted declarations detailing widespread program disruptions and financial distress (including staff furloughs/layoffs, shuttered offices, and stranded commodities) and later alleged that defendants intend to realign or retire substantial USAID functions and not obligate large portions of appropriated funds absent judicial relief.

Appeals followed. The government appealed the preliminary injunction (Nos. 25‑5097/5098). On August 13, 2025, a D.C. Circuit panel vacated the impoundment portion of the injunction, holding plaintiffs lacked a cause of action to press that claim, with a dissent. On August 20, 2025, the en banc D.C. Circuit entered an order stating that “the preliminary injunction that requires the government to obligate the appropriated funds remains in effect,” and the district court denied the government’s motion for a partial stay pending mandate. As of the latest district‑court orders, defendants continue to file periodic status reports and to process payments for pre‑TRO work, while the obligation/impoundment and termination issues remain under active enforcement and appellate review.
extracted.value: The case involves a challenge to the Executive Branch’s suspension and termination of U.S. foreign‑aid funding following President Trump’s January 20, 2025 Executive Order 14169. U.S. nonprofits and companies implementing State Department and USAID awards sued, alleging the government unlawfully froze obligations and disbursements, issued stop‑work orders, and mass‑terminated thousands of awards, ignoring Congress’s 2024 appropriations and statutory limits on impoundment. Plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, and the court granted a TRO on February 13, 2025, and a preliminary injunction on March 10, 2025, enjoining further terminations and requiring payment for work completed before February 13. The case is supported by evidence such as the executive order, the TRO and injunction orders, the government pause memorandum M‑25‑13, plaintiffs’ declarations of program disruptions, and subsequent appellate rulings.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: I identified the factual basis by extracting the plaintiffs’ allegations, the court’s orders and evidentiary hearings, the appellate court’s stays and vacatur, and the statutory context under Title X of the Dodd‑Frank Act, and compiled these into a concise summary.

evidence: Plaintiffs alleged that after a change in administration, the CFPB’s leadership took steps to dismantle the agency in defiance of Congress’s mandate in the Dodd‑Frank Act, including a February 10, 2025 bureau‑wide “stop‑work” email; cancellation of dozens of contracts (including in Enforcement, Supervision, and Consumer Response); firing of probationary and term employees; closing CFPB’s headquarters for a week; and plans for mass reductions in force (RIFs).
They sought declaratory and injunctive relief to prevent further shutdown actions and to preserve the Bureau’s statutorily required operations.

The court received testimony from CFPB Chief Operating Officer Adam Martinez and others regarding the February 10 stop‑work directive, contract cancellations, plans for an accelerated RIF, and the practical shutdown of key functions (including Consumer Response).

On March 28, 2025, the court issued a memorandum opinion and preliminary injunction. It found plaintiffs likely to succeed on separation‑of‑powers and APA claims, concluding the record showed defendants had undertaken “a concerted, expedited effort to shut the agency down entirely,” contrary to Congress’s mandate.

The order required defendants to: (1) preserve all CFPB records and data; (2) reinstate probationary and term employees terminated since February 10 (including the Private Student Loan Ombudsman); (3) refrain from terminating employees except for cause and from issuing RIF notices; (4) cease enforcing the February 10 stop‑work directive or achieving a work stoppage by other means (e.g., administrative leave edicts); (5) provide staff with office space or fully functional remote‑work capability; (6) ensure the Office of Consumer Response maintained the toll‑free number, website, and database and continued monitoring and responses, including escalated case management; and (7) rescind contract termination notices and refrain from finalizing further terminations absent individualized assessments that a contract was unnecessary to statutory functions.

Defendants noticed an appeal to the D.C. Circuit and sought a stay. On April 11, 2025, the D.C. Circuit partially stayed the injunction pending appeal, permitting terminations or RIFs, and targeted work stoppages, only after “particularized assessments” that affected employees or work were unnecessary to statutory duties, and staying the compliance‑report provision.

On April 17, 2025, defendants issued mass RIF notices to approximately 1,400–1,500 employees. Plaintiffs moved for an order to show cause; the district court held a hearing on April 18 and temporarily suspended the RIF and prohibited cutting off system access pending an evidentiary hearing, citing likely noncompliance with the injunction.

The D.C. Circuit clarified that a “particularized assessment” must determine, by the decisionmaker responsible for the RIF, that each CFPB division could perform statutorily required duties without the employees subject to RIF; and, sua sponte, lifted its partial stay of paragraph (3) of the preliminary injunction, restoring the district court’s blanket prohibition on RIFs to ensure meaningful final relief, while keeping other provisions as previously stayed.

The D.C. Circuit issued its decision on August 15, 2025, vacating the preliminary injunction and remanding. The court held that claims by the employee‑representative plaintiffs were channeled by the Civil Service Reform Act and thus outside district‑court jurisdiction; that the NAACP had associational standing; that plaintiffs’ APA claims failed because they did not target discrete, final agency action (the February 10 email was not final action, and the alleged “shutdown decision” was not a final, ripe, or discrete action under the APA); and that plaintiffs’ equitable separation‑of‑powers claim sounded in statutory ultra vires rather than a freestanding constitutional cause of action under Dalton v. Specter.

Key statutory context throughout was Title X of the Dodd‑Frank Act (12 U.S.C. § 5491 et seq.), which created the CFPB, assigned it rulemaking, supervision, enforcement, and specific mandatory duties (including consumer complaint intake and response, reporting obligations, and specialized offices), and established its funding outside annual appropriations.

Following an emergency filing, the court (Judge Amy Berman Jackson) entered a consent order on February 14, 2025 preserving agency data, prohibiting terminations except for cause and notices of RIF, and preventing transfers of reserve funds pending resolution of the preliminary‑injunction motion.
extracted.value: The case involves the National Treasury Employees Union and additional plaintiffs filing an action against the CFPB alleging that after a change in administration, the agency’s leadership undertook a concerted effort to dismantle the CFPB—including a February 10, 2025 stop‑work email, cancellation of contracts, termination of probationary and term employees, closing the headquarters, and plans for mass RIFs—claiming non‑statutory ultra‑vires and APA violations and seeking injunctive relief; the district court issued a preliminary injunction on March 28, 2025 ordering preservation of records, reinstatement of employees, and prohibition of further terminations; the D.C. Circuit partially stayed the injunction on April 11, 2025, allowing terminations subject to particularized assessments, but later vacated the injunction on August 15, 2025, finding plaintiffs’ claims barred by the Civil Service Reform Act and APA requirements, with the statutory framework under Title X of the Dodd‑Frank Act underpinning the CFPB’s functions.

Circuit clarified that a “particularized assessment” must determine, by the decisionmaker responsible for the RIF, that each CFPB division could perform statutorily required duties without the employees subject to RIF; and, sua sponte, lifted its partial stay of paragraph (3) of the preliminary injunction, restoring the district court’s blanket prohibition on RIFs to ensure meaningful final relief, while keeping other provisions as previously stayed.
extracted.value: On April 28, 2025, the D.C. Circuit clarified the meaning of a particularized assessment, and sua sponte lifted its partial stay of paragraph (3) of the preliminary injunction, restoring the blanket prohibition on RIFs while keeping other provisions stayed.

evidence: Separately, a related appeal of the April 18 interim order was voluntarily dismissed as moot on May 12, 2025.
extracted.value: On May 12, 2025, the D.C. Circuit voluntarily dismissed the related appeal of the April 18 interim order as moot.

evidence: On the merits appeal, the D.C. Circuit issued its decision on August 15, 2025, vacating the preliminary injunction and remanding. The court held that claims by the employee‑representative plaintiffs were channeled by the Civil Service Reform Act and thus outside district‑court jurisdiction; that the NAACP had associational standing; that plaintiffs’ APA claims failed because they did not target discrete, final agency action (the February 10 email was not final action, and the alleged “shutdown decision” was not a final, ripe, or discrete action under the APA); and that plaintiffs’ equitable separation‑of‑powers claim sounded in statutory ultra vires rather than a freestanding constitutional cause of action under Dalton v. Specter. Judge Pillard dissented.
extracted.value: On August 15, 2025, the D.C. Circuit vacated the preliminary injunction and remanded the case, finding employee‑representative claims were outside district‑court jurisdiction, the NAACP had associational standing, APA claims failed, and the equitable separation‑of‑powers claim was statutory ultra vires.

evidence: On August 12, 2013, the court issued a Remedies Opinion in Floyd and Ligon ordering systemic reforms: revising NYPD policies on investigative encounters (clarifying what constitutes a Terry stop, the reasonable‑suspicion standard, and that a frisk requires separate reasonable suspicion that a person is armed and dangerous), prohibiting racial profiling, improving training and supervision, auditing, and instituting a one‑year body‑worn camera (BWC) pilot, as well as a community‑based Joint Remedial Process.
extracted.value: The remedies opinion in August 2013 mandated systemic reforms, including revised investigative encounter policies, clarified Terry stop and reasonable suspicion standards, prohibited racial profiling, required training, and instituted a one‑year BWC pilot and a Joint Remedial Process.

evidence: On July 19, 2017, the parties executed a Stipulation of Settlement and Order that fully resolved Ligon. Without admitting liability, the City agreed to adopt and implement detailed standards for enforcement in and around TAP buildings and to incorporate oversight under the Floyd/Ligon remedial monitoring. The settlement tightened NYPD rules so that mere presence in, entry into, or exit from a TAP building cannot justify a Level 1 approach, a Level 2 accusatory inquiry, or a Level 3 stop; required documentation of every Level 3 stop (including narrative articulation of reasonable suspicion and, separately, grounds for any frisk or search); required probable cause for arrests or summonses; prohibited frisks absent reasonable suspicion that a person is armed and dangerous; and mandated completion of a standardized Trespass Crimes Fact Sheet prior to arraignment for every trespass arrest in or around a TAP building.
extracted.value: The July 19, 2017 settlement required the city to adopt enforcement standards, document Level 3 stops, require probable cause for arrests, prohibit frisks absent reasonable suspicion, mandate a Trespass Crimes Fact Sheet, revise patrol guide and administrative guide, and train personnel on new policies.

evidence: Under oversight by Monitor Zimroth, the NYPD issued and implemented revised policies on investigative encounters (P.G. 212‑11) and racial profiling (P.G. 203‑25), and adopted the court‑approved Trespass Crimes Fact Sheet. The monitor launched a randomized BWC pilot in patrol precincts and a quasi‑experimental BWC evaluation in Housing Bureau PSAs, and reported on implementation, training, supervision, auditing, and performance‑evaluation changes, including NYPD’s RISKS Reviews to address underreporting and supervisory shortcomings.
extracted.value: Monitor Zimroth oversaw implementation of revised policies, a randomized BWC pilot, and a quasi‑experimental BWC evaluation, reporting on training, supervision, auditing, and performance evaluation changes, including RISKS Reviews.

evidence: On July 19, 2017, the parties executed a Stipulation of Settlement and Order that fully resolved Ligon.

Without admitting liability, the City agreed to adopt and implement detailed standards for enforcement in and around TAP buildings and to incorporate oversight under the Floyd/Ligon remedial monitoring. The settlement tightened NYPD rules so that mere presence in, entry into, or exit from a TAP building cannot justify a Level 1 approach, a Level 2 accusatory inquiry, or a Level 3 stop; required documentation of every Level 3 stop (including narrative articulation of reasonable suspicion and, separately, grounds for any frisk or search); required probable cause for arrests or summonses; prohibited frisks absent reasonable suspicion that a person is armed and dangerous; and mandated completion of a standardized Trespass Crimes Fact Sheet prior to arraignment for every trespass arrest in or around a TAP building. The NYPD agreed to revise Patrol Guide § 212‑59 (interior patrols of TAP buildings) and Administrative Guide § 303‑27 (TAP administration), including enrollment and periodic renewal criteria tied to crime or complaints and higher‑level approvals for extended participation. The Department committed to training all personnel engaged in TAP enforcement and TAP administration on these standards, and to provide roll‑call, in‑service, promotional, and recruit training consistent with the revised policies (including the investigative encounters policy, P.G. 212‑11, and the racial profiling policy, P.G. 203‑25). The court retained jurisdiction to enforce the settlement, incorporated the Floyd remedial monitoring (with substantial‑compliance benchmarks), and provided for a second remedial phase of document production and review following the monitor’s tenure. The City agreed to pay $235,000 in damages to named plaintiffs and to pay class counsel’s reasonable fees and costs ($2,585,101 in fees and $55,432 in costs through June 30, 2016, plus additional negotiated interim fees).
extracted.value: On July 19, 2017, the parties executed a Stipulation of Settlement and Order that fully resolved Ligon, with the City adopting detailed enforcement standards around TAP buildings, paying $235,000 in damages to named plaintiffs, and agreeing to pay class counsel’s fees and costs, while the court retained jurisdiction to enforce the settlement and incorporated the Floyd remedial monitoring.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: I identified the factual basis by locating the paragraph that enumerates concrete denials arising from DOMA Section 3 across federal programs, and the preceding paragraph that sets out the plaintiffs’ legal theory. These provide the events, evidence, and background needed for the factual basis.

evidence: The factual basis of the case showed concrete denials flowing from DOMA’s marriage definition across multiple federal programs: (1) a retired federal civilian employee and her wife were barred from converting Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) coverage to “Self & Family” to cover the spouse; (2) a Postal Service employee was denied Family and Medical Leave Act leave to care for her wife and the couple was refused FEHB “Self & Family” coverage; (3) a widower was denied both the Social Security one‑time lump‑sum death benefit and a qualified preretirement survivor annuity under an ERISA‑governed defined‑benefit plan because his marriage was not recognized; (4) two retired New Hampshire teachers were denied a spousal medical cost supplement from the state retirement system because federal tax law (as applied through DOMA) limited § 401(h) retiree medical benefits to opposite‑sex “spouses”; (5) two married couples were denied the right to file joint federal income tax returns (and resulting refunds); and (6) a federal attorney was denied the ability to add his husband to existing FEHB family coverage, forcing purchase of private insurance.

The plaintiffs asserted a federal question and sought declaratory and injunctive relief under 28 U.S.C. §§ 1331 and 2201–2202 (and program‑specific judicial review statutes including 5 U.S.C. § 8912, 29 U.S.C. § 2617(a)(2), and 42 U.S.C. § 405(g)). Their legal theory was that DOMA Section 3, as applied to them, violated the equal protection component of the Fifth Amendment by denying federal recognition of valid state marriages and the spousal benefits and obligations that follow.
extracted.value: The case involves same‑sex couples and a surviving spouse who were denied federal benefits under DOMA Section 3, including FEHB coverage, FMLA leave, Social Security death benefit, survivor annuity, state retirement medical supplement, joint tax filings, and the ability to add a spouse to FEHB coverage. These denials were supported by specific instances such as a retired federal civilian employee and her wife barred from converting FEHB coverage, a Postal Service employee denied FMLA leave, a widower denied Social Security benefit, two retired New Hampshire teachers denied a medical cost supplement, two married couples denied joint tax returns, and a federal attorney denied adding his husband to FEHB coverage. Background context includes the plaintiffs being lawfully married in Connecticut, Vermont, and New Hampshire, the DOJ's decision to no longer defend DOMA, the intervention of BLAG, and the legal theory that DOMA violated the Fifth Amendment equal protection clause.

plaintiffs asserted a federal question and sought declaratory and injunctive relief under 28 U.S.C. §§ 1331 and 2201–2202 (and program‑specific judicial review statutes including 5 U.S.C. § 8912, 29 U.S.C. § 2617(a)(2), and 42 U.S.C. § 405(g)). Their legal theory was that DOMA Section 3, as applied to them, violated the equal protection component of the Fifth Amendment by denying federal recognition of valid state marriages and the spousal benefits and obligations that follow. Specific remedies included declarations that Section 3 is unconstitutional as applied, injunctions against its enforcement with respect to federal benefits, and, for the tax‑filing couples, appropriate refunds (with the United States named under 26 U.S.C. § 7422(f)(1)).

evidence: By March 2017 and through 2019, the monitor consistently found substantial compliance in most areas, with improvements including: widespread PREA and refresher training; robust inmate education and orientation; functioning internal and external reporting systems (ADECA hotline and third‑party reporting); a PREA‑trained investigations unit with timely, policy‑compliant investigations; expanded cameras and annual camera reviews; cross‑gender privacy and search policies implemented facility‑wide; gender‑responsive LGBTI policies and practices; a functioning grievance system; a quality improvement program and RMS with biannual and annual reviews; and implementation of the WRNA and women’s programming (e.g., Helping Women Recover, Beyond Trauma, Beyond Violence, Active Adult Relationships, Moving On, Parenting Inside Out, and reentry programming). evidence: Two persistent challenges remained. First, correctional staffing: despite a finalized staffing plan (July 2017) and implementation of many of its recommendations (including shift changes, recruitment initiatives, and overtime controls), Tutwiler continued to have significant officer vacancies, requiring overtime, post “doubling,” and occasional use of supervisors in line posts. Recruitment and retention of women officers, validation of APOSTC standards, and long‑term staffing sufficiency remained in partial compliance.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: I identified the factual basis by locating the passage describing the filing of the suit, the plaintiffs, the claims, the amendment text, and the subsequent injunctions. These details comprise the facts upon which the case is built.

evidence: "On November 8, 2006, the day after Michigan voters approved “Proposal 2” amending the state constitution to prohibit public institutions from discriminating against or granting preferential treatment based on race, sex, color, ethnicity, or national origin in public higher education, employment, and contracting (Mich. Const. art. I, § 26), several organizations and individuals filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan."

"The plaintiffs included civil‑rights groups (BAMN, UEAALDF, Rainbow PUSH), unions, students, prospective applicants, and a student political party. They sued the Governor and the governing boards of the University of Michigan, Michigan State University, and Wayne State University, later adding the Michigan Attorney General as a defendant and asserting claims under 42 U.S.C. § 1983. They alleged violations of the Equal Protection Clause—both as intentional discrimination and under the “political structure” doctrine of Hunter v. Erickson and Washington v. Seattle School Dist. No. 1—preemption by Titles VI, VII, and IX, and infringement of universities’ First Amendment academic freedom, and sought declaratory and injunctive relief barring enforcement of Proposal 2."

"On December 11, 2006, the university defendants filed a cross‑claim for declaratory relief and a preliminary injunction to postpone Proposal 2’s effective date during the then‑ongoing admissions cycle. The district court entered a stipulated temporary injunction on December 19, 2006, delaying application of § 26 to university admissions and financial aid through June 30, 2007, but the Sixth Circuit stayed that order on December 29, 2006 (Coalition to Defend Aff…)."
extracted.value: The case involves the filing of a lawsuit on November 8, 2006 by civil‑rights groups, unions, students, prospective applicants, and a student political party against the Governor and university boards after Michigan voters approved Proposal 2, alleging violations of the Equal Protection Clause and other claims under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, supported by the amendment’s text, the plaintiffs’ claims, and the subsequent court orders, with background information such as the amendment’s prohibition on race‑based preferences in public higher education and the legal arguments referencing Hunter and Seattle and the political‑process doctrine.

evidence: On August 22, 2005, a wheelchair user sued a national restaurant chain in the Southern District of California under Title III of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), 42 U.S.C. § 12181 et seq., and California access laws (the Unruh Civil Rights Act and the California Disabled Persons Act (CDPA)).
He sought declaratory and injunctive relief and damages under state law.
extracted.value: The plaintiff, a wheelchair user, filed a lawsuit against Chipotle on August 22, 2005, invoking ADA, Unruh, and CDPA, and sought declaratory and injunctive relief and damages under state law.

evidence: The plaintiff alleged that two newly constructed Chipotle Mexican Grill restaurants in San Diego (Pacific Beach) and Encinitas denied him full and equal enjoyment of their goods and services.
extracted.value: Plaintiff alleged that the Pacific Beach and Encinitas Chipotle locations denied him full and equal enjoyment.

evidence: He cited inaccessible parking, entrances, and restrooms, and principally challenged a 44-inch wall (46 inches with sneeze guard bracket) along the food preparation counter that blocked wheelchair users—whose average eye level is 43–51 inches—from seeing the food being prepared and displayed, which he argued was central to the “Chipotle experience.”
extracted.value: Plaintiff cited inaccessible parking, entrances, restrooms, and a 44‑inch wall blocking wheelchair users' view of food preparation.

evidence: At the time of the visits (2005–2006), Chipotle had an unwritten practice of accommodating customers with disabilities by holding up serving spoons or cups of food or moving food to a side counter or table; in February 2007, it adopted a written “Customers With Disabilities” policy to formalize such accommodations.
extracted.value: Chipotle had an unwritten accommodation practice during visits and adopted a written policy in February 2007.

evidence: The court (Judge Napoleon A. Jones, Jr.) granted in part and denied in part cross‑motions for summary judgment on June 14, 2007. The court held that the food area was governed by ADAAG § 7.2 (sales and service counters), not § 4.33.3 (fixed seating/assembly areas).
extracted.value: Court determined that the counter area was governed by ADAAG §7.2, not §4.33.3.

evidence: It found Chipotle’s lowered transaction station did not satisfy § 7.2(2)(i) or (ii), and set for trial the question whether Chipotle provided “equivalent facilitation” under § 7.2(2)(iii).
extracted.value: The lowered transaction station did not satisfy §7.2(2)(i) or (ii) and equivalent facilitation was subject to trial.

evidence: The court also found ADA violations in the parking lots during some of the plaintiff’s visits but, because those had been corrected, dismissed the ADA claims as moot and reserved CDPA damages; ADA claims regarding entrances, restrooms, and seating were resolved or deemed outside the pleadings.
extracted.value: Court found parking lot ADA violations, dismissed them as moot, reserved CDPA damages; other ADA claims were resolved or outside pleadings.

evidence: Following a four‑day bench trial in November–December 2007, the court ruled that Chipotle’s unwritten practice of accommodation did not constitute equivalent facilitation but that its 2007 written policy did.
extracted.value: Bench trial ruled unwritten practice was not equivalent facilitation; written policy was.

evidence: The court denied injunctive relief and awarded $5,000 in CDPA statutory damages ($1,000 per visit) for five “bona fide” visits before the written policy; it denied damages for three visits undertaken primarily to gather evidence.
extracted.value: Court awarded $5,000 CDPA damages for five bona fide visits and denied damages for evidence‑gathering visits.

evidence: On April 21, 2008, it denied the plaintiff’s motion to amend the findings.
extracted.value: Court denied motion to amend findings on April 21, 2008.

evidence: The court later awarded the plaintiff $136,537.83 in attorneys’ fees; each side bore its own costs.
extracted.value: Court awarded plaintiff $136,537.83 attorneys’ fees; parties bore their own costs.

evidence: In a published decision, Antoninetti v. Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., 643 F.3d 1165 (9th Cir. 2010), the Ninth Circuit affirmed that § 7.2 governs Chipotle’s counters and that the lowered transaction station was not a “portion” of the main counter or an auxiliary counter under § 7.2(2)(i) or (ii). It reversed the district court’s ruling that the written policy constituted equivalent facilitation under § 7.2(2)(iii), holding that showing samples or assembling food at another location did not provide “substantially equivalent or greater access to and usability of the facility.” The court concluded that Chipotle violated the ADA, vacated the denial of injunctive relief as an abuse of discretion, and remanded for entry of an appropriate injunction. It also vacated the damages award and remanded for further proceedings, noting that damages under the CDPA are available for visits when the plaintiff “actually presented himself … with the intent of being served and to purchase food … and actually encountered” unequal access. The Ninth Circuit vacated the fee award and directed reconsideration in light of the changed outcome.
extracted.value: Ninth Circuit affirmed ADAAG §7.2 governs counters, reversed written policy facilitation ruling, vacated denial of injunctive relief and damages award, vacated fee award.

evidence: On remand before Judge Barry Ted Moskowitz, the court entered judgment for the plaintiff on the ADA violation and set proceedings on injunctive relief and damages. Chipotle represented that it had lowered food preparation counters at all California restaurants; the court permitted limited discovery to evaluate mootness and how to ensure permanent compliance. Before injunctive relief could be fashioned, the plaintiff passed away on May 9, 2011. On March 21, 2012, the court denied injunctive relief as moot and awarded $5,000 in CDPA damages for five “bona fide” visits; it again denied damages for three litigation‑related visits under the Ninth Circuit’s guidance. The court later reconsidered fees and, in 2012, awarded substantially increased fees (over $500,000) and costs for district court work and for successfully opposing Chipotle’s petition for a writ of certiorari; the Ninth Circuit separately awarded appellate fees.
extracted.value: On remand, court entered judgment for ADA violation, denied injunctive relief as moot, awarded $5,000 CDPA damages, denied litigation‑related damages, later awarded >$500,000 fees.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: I identified the factual basis by extracting the key facts: plaintiffs’ status, the law challenged, the alleged claims, and the court’s findings.

evidence: In June 2019, several lawsuits were filed in the Northern District of Florida and later consolidated as Jones v. DeSantis (No. 4:19‑cv‑300). The individual plaintiffs were Florida residents with past felony convictions who had completed incarceration and supervision but still owed court-imposed financial obligations; organizational plaintiffs were the Florida State Conference of the NAACP, the Orange County Branch of the NAACP, and the League of Women Voters of Florida, which conduct voter registration and education.

Proceeding under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, the plaintiffs challenged Senate Bill 7066—enacted after Florida voters approved Amendment 4 in November 2018—which defined “completion of all terms of sentence” to include payment of fines, fees, costs, and restitution.

They alleged (i) wealth-based discrimination in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment’s Equal Protection Clause; (ii) an unconstitutional “poll tax or other tax” under the Twenty‑Fourth Amendment; (iii) violations of the Due Process Clause due to vagueness and the risk of erroneous deprivation of the right to vote; and (iv) related statutory claims (including the National Voter Registration Act and, in some complaints, the Voting Rights Act).

Based on extensive factual findings—including that Florida lacked a reliable process to determine what LFOs were owed and paid, and that most affected individuals were indigent—the court held that Florida could not condition voting on LFOs a person was genuinely unable to pay; that court fees and costs functioned as “other taxes” barred by the Twenty‑Fourth Amendment; and that the State’s implementation created a substantial risk of erroneous deprivation and deterred lawful voting.
extracted.value: The case involves plaintiffs who are Florida residents with past felony convictions who, after completing incarceration and supervision, still owed court‑imposed financial obligations (LFOs). They were denied the right to register or vote because Florida’s SB 7066, enacted after Amendment 4, defined “completion of all terms of sentence” to include payment of fines, fees, costs, and restitution. The plaintiffs alleged wealth‑based discrimination, a poll tax violation, and due‑process violations. The court found that Florida lacked a reliable process to determine LFO balances, that most affected individuals were indigent, and that conditioning voting on payment of LFOs constituted a Twenty‑Fourth Amendment tax and created a substantial risk of erroneous deprivation of voting rights.

It also ordered a streamlined advisory‑opinion process through the Division of Elections to confirm eligibility or inability to pay.
extracted.value: On May 24, 2020, Judge Hinkle permanently enjoined enforcement of SB 7066 to the extent it required payment of fees and costs as a condition of voting, required payment of fines or restitution that a person genuinely could not pay, or required payment of amounts that could not be determined with diligence, and ordered a streamlined advisory‑opinion process.

evidence: On February 19, 2020, the Eleventh Circuit affirmed the preliminary injunction (950 F.3d 795), holding that heightened scrutiny applied to wealth‑based discrimination in this context and that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their Equal Protection claim as applied to those unable to pay.
extracted.value: On February 19, 2020, the Eleventh Circuit affirmed the preliminary injunction and held that heightened scrutiny applied to wealth‑based discrimination.

evidence: On September 11, 2020, sitting en banc, the Eleventh Circuit reversed (975 F.3d 1016), vacated the injunction, and upheld SB 7066. The majority held that rational‑basis review applies to felon reenfranchisement classifications; that requiring completion of all sentencing terms, including LFOs, is rationally related to legitimate state interests; that court‑imposed fees and costs are punitive, not “taxes,” and therefore do not violate the Twenty‑Fourth Amendment; and that Florida’s procedures—including notice and hearings before removal from the rolls and an advisory‑opinion mechanism—did not violate due process or render the scheme void for vagueness.
extracted.value: On September 11, 2020, the Eleventh Circuit en banc reversed and vacated the permanent injunction, upheld SB 7066, and held that rational‑basis review applies to felon reenfranchisement classifications.

evidence: On July 16, 2020, the Supreme Court denied an application to vacate an appellate stay; Justice Sotomayor, joined by Justices Ginsburg and Kagan, dissented.
extracted.value: On July 16, 2020, the Florida Supreme Court denied an application to vacate an appellate stay.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: The summary provides a clear narrative of the class action, the plaintiffs’ allegations that foster children were denied medically necessary mental health services, and the subsequent court orders and appellate decision. I extracted the core factual basis by compiling the filing date, the specific allegations, the evidence from the complaint and court orders, and the contextual background such as EPSDT, the ADA, Section 504, and due process rights.

evidence: Filed on July 18, 2002, this class action challenged the failure to provide medically necessary mental health services to foster children in Los Angeles County and statewide in California.

Factually, plaintiffs alleged that tens of thousands of foster children with behavioral, emotional, or psychiatric impairments were not being provided medically necessary services (e.g., assessments, intensive home‑based services, case management, “wraparound” services, and therapeutic foster care) and were instead over‑relied upon institutional placements and experienced repeated placement disruptions.

The First Amended Complaint (December 20, 2002) asserted federal claims under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 to enforce Medicaid’s Early and Periodic Screening, Diagnostic, and Treatment (EPSDT) provisions, and alleged violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act, Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and federal and state due process.

On March 14, 2006, the district court granted a preliminary injunction (433 F. Supp. 2d 1065) requiring the State to provide wraparound services and therapeutic foster care to class members on a consistent statewide basis through Medi‑Cal or other means, and issued a clarifying addendum on May 12, 2006.

The Ninth Circuit denied a stay but, on March 23, 2007, reversed and remanded (481 F.3d 1150), holding that EPSDT requires provision of the component services listed in 42 U.S.C. § 1396d(a), and directing the district court to determine whether those components were being effectively provided, rather than requiring specific “bundled” programs; it confirmed a § 1983 private right of action under § 1396a(a)(10).
extracted.value: The case involves a class action filed on July 18, 2002, alleging that tens of thousands of foster children with documented mental health needs across California were not receiving medically necessary services (such as assessments, intensive home‑based services, case management, wraparound services, and therapeutic foster care), and were over‑reliant on institutional placements and experienced repeated placement disruptions, supported by the plaintiffs’ complaint, the district court’s preliminary injunction, and the Ninth Circuit’s decision, with background context including Medicaid’s EPSDT provisions, the ADA, Section 504, and due process rights.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: I examined the case summary and identified key factual elements—filing date, parties, allegations against OP 830.A, conditions alleged, court rulings, and appellate outcome—then extracted those facts with supporting evidence snippets.

evidence: On December 19, 2014, a Virginia state prisoner filed an individual civil rights action under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 in the Western District of Virginia against the state corrections department and numerous corrections officials at system and facility level.
The prisoner proceeded pro se in the district court; the defendants were represented by the Virginia Office of the Attorney General.
The court denied the prisoner’s motion to certify a class and his request for appointment of counsel.
Two co‑plaintiffs originally named were severed, leaving a single plaintiff.

The suit challenged Virginia Department of Corrections Operating Procedure 830.A governing “Level S” segregation at Red Onion State Prison and Wallens Ridge State Prison, alleging that the classification and review procedures kept him in highly restrictive solitary conditions without constitutionally adequate process and that those conditions violated the Eighth Amendment.

The prisoner, serving a 38‑year sentence for violent offenses and convicted in 2011 of malicious wounding after a 2009 assault on a guard, had been designated a Level S “Intensive Management” (IM) inmate at Red Onion.
Under OP 830.A, Level S inmates are divided into Intensive Management and Special Management (SM) paths.

SM inmates may progress through a goal‑oriented Step‑Down program toward general population, while IM inmates progress through IM‑0, IM‑1, and IM‑2 “privilege levels,” and, if approved, to an IM Closed Pod (IM‑SL6) intended to improve quality of life for those facing long‑term high security.
Level S inmates receive periodic Institutional Classification Authority reviews at least every 90 days.

The prisoner contended that IM status effectively barred him from meaningful progress out of segregation, that reviews were arbitrary or perfunctory, and that IM inmates were subjected to harsher conditions than similarly situated SM inmates, violating equal protection.
He sought declaratory and injunctive relief (including abolishing OP 830.A and altering conditions) and monetary damages.

The prisoner described conditions that included single‑cell housing, meals in cell, three showers per week, one hour of out‑of‑cell recreation five days per week (alone in a secure area), restraints and escorts whenever out of cell, non‑contact visits, limited phone and commissary privileges, constant lighting, noise, and other restrictions he alleged caused mental and physical harms.
The defendants submitted OP 830.A and related classification procedures, and an affidavit explaining the Level S program, IM/SM tracks, privileges, and review mechanisms.
On September 28, 2016, Judge James P. Jones granted summary judgment to all remaining defendants and dismissed the claim against the Virginia Department of Corrections as legally frivolous.

The court held that the plaintiff failed to show a Fourteenth Amendment due process violation, finding that under OP 830.A he received periodic, multi‑level reviews of his status and opportunities to advance in step‑down and privilege levels; and that his restrictive conditions and duration, in light of his offense and institutional record, did not establish deprivation of a protected liberty interest without due process.

The court also rejected his Eighth Amendment claim, concluding he had not shown deprivation of a basic human need such as food, shelter, or medical care, deliberate indifference by officials, or injury rising to constitutional magnitude.
The court denied the equal protection claim for lack of evidence of purposeful discrimination among similarly situated inmates.
On November 22, 2017, a Fourth Circuit panel (Judges Niemeyer, King, and Floyd) issued an unpublished per curiam decision affirming the district court’s judgment.
No trial occurred, and there were no decrees or settlements.
extracted.value: The case involves a Virginia state prisoner who filed a §1983 action on December 19, 2014, alleging that the Department of Corrections Operating Procedure 830.A kept him in Level S “Intensive Management” segregation without adequate due process or Eighth Amendment protection. He claimed the procedure barred him from meaningful progress, that reviews were arbitrary, and that his restrictive conditions (single‑cell housing, meals in cell, limited recreation, restraints, constant lighting, etc.) caused mental and physical harm. He also alleged equal protection violations, claiming IM inmates were subjected to harsher conditions than SM inmates. The defendants submitted the OP 830.A and an affidavit explaining the Level S program. The court denied class certification and counsel, granted a protective order, denied the motion to dismiss, granted leave to amend, and ultimately granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants, dismissing the claim against the VDOC as frivolous. The Fourth Circuit affirmed the district court’s judgment on November 22, 2017. Background: the prisoner was serving a 38‑year sentence for violent offenses, convicted in 2011 of malicious wounding after a 2009 assault on a guard, and had been designated Level S IM at Red Onion State Prison.

evidence: On December 19, 2006, in consolidated appeals that included the Baltimore City APA case and other challenges, the Maryland Court of Appeals (opinion by Judge Alan M. Wilner) held: (1) the Execution Operations Manual’s three‑drug mix and method (including use of two paralytic agents) did not conflict with § 3‑905 and were not unconstitutional on their face; but (2) the detailed “Lethal Injection Checklist,” which specified the contents and manner of administering the drugs, was a “regulation” under the APA because it had general application and future effect and implemented the death penalty statute. Because the Division of Correction had not adopted the checklist pursuant to APA rulemaking (notice, review by the Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive, and Legislative Review, and publication), it was ineffective. The Court of Appeals vacated the denial of injunctive relief and remanded with instructions to enjoin enforcement of the Lethal Injection Checklist until it was properly adopted as a regulation under the APA or exempted by the General Assembly. See Evans v. State, 396 Md. 256 (2006).

The Court vacated the denial of injunctive relief and remanded to enjoin enforcement of the Checklist until properly adopted or exempted.

Wilner) held: (1) the Execution Operations Manual’s three‑drug mix and method (including use of two paralytic agents) did not conflict with § 3‑905 and were not unconstitutional on their face; but (2) the detailed “Lethal Injection Checklist,” which specified the contents and manner of administering the drugs, was a “regulation” under the APA because it had general application and future effect and implemented the death penalty statute. Because the Division of Correction had not adopted the checklist pursuant to APA rulemaking (notice, review by the Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive, and Legislative Review, and publication), it was ineffective. The Court of Appeals vacated the denial of injunctive relief and remanded with instructions to enjoin enforcement of the Lethal Injection Checklist until it was properly adopted as a regulation under the APA or exempted by the General Assembly. See Evans v. State, 396 Md. 256 (2006).
extracted.value: Evans v. State, 396 Md. 256 (2006); a consolidated appeal in the Maryland Court of Appeals that included the Baltimore City APA case and other challenges. The court held that the Execution Operations Manual’s three‑drug mix was not unconstitutional, but the Lethal Injection Checklist was an ineffective APA regulation, vacated denial of injunctive relief, and remanded to enjoin enforcement until proper APA compliance.

Factual Basis of Case.reasoning: I identified the factual basis by extracting statements that describe the key events, the evidence presented, and the court decisions, and then summarizing them into a concise narrative.

evidence: On January 19, 2006, a condemned Maryland inmate filed a federal civil rights action under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services, the Commissioner of the Division of Correction, two wardens, and unnamed execution team members, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief to bar his execution under Maryland’s current lethal injection practices.

The prisoner argued that the three‑drug protocol (sodium thiopental, pancuronium bromide, and potassium chloride), the lack of anesthesiology‑qualified personnel, long IV runs across two rooms, and the absence of monitoring for anesthetic depth created a grave and unnecessary risk that he would experience excruciating pain in violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.
He cited, among other things, a 1998 execution in which an IV line leaked and the procedure lasted 23 minutes, and he contended his history of intravenous drug use would complicate venous access.

On February 1, 2006, Judge Legg denied both a temporary restraining order and a preliminary injunction, finding the inmate had not shown a likelihood of success on the merits under the governing preliminary injunction standard and that Maryland’s protocol, if properly implemented, would render an inmate deeply unconscious before administering the paralytic and potassium chloride.

On December 19, 2006, in consolidated appeals that included the Baltimore City APA case and other challenges, the Maryland Court of Appeals (opinion by Judge Alan M. Wilner) held: (1) the Execution Operations Manual’s three‑drug mix and method (including use of two paralytic agents) did not conflict with § 3‑905 and were not unconstitutional on their face; but (2) the detailed “Lethal Injection Checklist,” which specified the contents and manner of administering the drugs, was a “regulation” under the APA because it had general application and future effect and implemented the death penalty statute.

Because the Division of Correction had not adopted the checklist pursuant to APA rulemaking (notice, review by the Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive, and Legislative Review, and publication), it was ineffective.

The Court of Appeals vacated the denial of injunctive relief and remanded with instructions to enjoin enforcement of the Lethal Injection Checklist until it was properly adopted as a regulation under the APA or exempted by the General Assembly.
As a result, Maryland executions were stayed pending APA compliance.
extracted.value: The case involves a 42 U.S.C. § 1983 action filed on January 19, 2006, by a condemned inmate alleging Maryland’s lethal injection protocol posed a grave risk of excruciating pain due to inadequate anesthetic monitoring and procedural deficiencies, supported by evidence of a 1998 execution incident, the inmate’s intravenous drug use history, and expert testimony; the case also includes a state APA action where the Maryland Court of Appeals held the Lethal Injection Checklist was an ineffective regulation, resulting in a stay of executions pending APA compliance.
